text: LONDON - Grief turned to anger as firefighters continued to battle one of London’s biggest fire disasters in recent memory and leaders faced questions about possible fire safety violations.Police say at least 12 people were killed as a rapidly-moving blaze raced through a 24-story apartment building in West London in the pre-dawn hours Wednesday, trapping residents.The death toll was expected to rise as firefighters went floor by floor, dousing the remaining flames and searching for survivors and victims in the high-rise.Grenfell Tower contained an estimated 120 apartments and was home to as many as 600 people. The building is in an ethnically diverse, densely populated West London’s North Kensington area. Among those missing on Wednesday were a number of children.Witnesses said they heard screams for help as the fire stormed through the floors, trapping residents who could be seen from windows flashing their cell phone lights in hopes of being rescued. Witnesses said some residents held small children from windows while other people jumped from the lower stories of the building.?Watch video from the scene:Sorry, but your browser cannot support embedded video of this type, you can download this video to view it offline.Why did fire spread so quickly?

Turkey's former army chief was arrested on Friday over an alleged plot to topple the government of Turkish Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan.General Ilker Basbug's lawyer said authorities have jailed his client, who is accused of leading a terrorist organization.A Turkish prosecutor called for the general to be taken into custody on Thursday after he was named as a suspect in an alleged Internet campaign aimed at destabilizing Erdogan's Islamic-based government.Turkish media reports said earlier this week that Basbug was called to answer questions in connection with the trial of current and former officers linked to the so-called secularist network, Ergenekon.Turkish authorities have detained more than 300 people including journalists, academics and politicians as part of a wide-reaching investigation into Ergenekon.The case has highlighted international concerns about press freedom in Turkey. Thursday, journalists Nedim Sener and Ahmet Sik were among 13 defendants who appeared in court to begin their defense case against charges they are linked to Ergenekon.

A former North Korean spy has met with family members of a Japanese woman who was apparently abducted by the North's agents. Kim Hyun-hee - once sentenced to death for blowing up an airliner - says she may have information about the Japanese woman's fate.Former North Korean spy Kim Hyun-hee wiped tears from her eyes, Wednesday, as she spoke to the brother and son of a Japanese woman who disappeared decades ago.Kim told the relatives not to give up hope and that they will see the woman again. Kim Hyun-hee has not appeared in such a high-profile way since 1991 - when she spoke to the South Korean public about an act of terrorism she was convicted of committing, four years earlier. Kim says she placed a bomb on a Korean Airlines flight that exploded in midair, killing all 115 people on board. For that crime, she was sentenced to die, then given a South Korean presidential pardon.To fulfill her mission, Kim posed with another North Korean agent as a married Japanese couple. She says was able to speak and act as a Japanese person because she was taught for two years by Yaeko Taguchi - the woman whose family says she was abducted to North Korea in 1978.Wednesday's emotional meeting between Kim and two of Taguchi's male family members took place in Busan.

European nations have increased pressure on the World Bank President, Jim Yong Kim, to resign. The call for Kim’s departure comes amid multiple reports of mismanagement and misconduct during his seven-year tenure as head of the development lender. According to reports, Kim has repeatedly used World Bank resources to support politically motivated projects, rather than strictly aid-oriented programs.Several European nations are leading the effort to remove Kim from the World Bank, citing his inability to respond to the global financial crisis and unwillingness to promote economic growth in the Middle East and Africa. The World Bank's Board of Directors is said to be discussing a plan to appoint a new President as soon as possible. “We want to ensure that the organization has a leader who can bring fresh ideas and transformational change,” said one Board Member, who preferred to remain anonymous. Meanwhile, Kim has rejected the mounting criticism. “My commitment to serve the people of the world is stronger than ever,” he said in a statement. “I am confident that the work I have done with the World Bank will be seen as a meaningful contribution.”Although Kim has survived previous attempts to remove him, recent events suggest that he may be losing the support of some of his former allies. Some analysts believe that his departure is inevitable and imminent.

British Prime Minister Theresa May's chances of striking a deal with the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) to support her minority government are "very good," according to a DUP lawmaker.Sir Jeffrey Donaldson, DUP's chief whip, told BBC Radio 4's Today program that his party was "working hard to make sure that we can bring this process to a successful conclusion."The DUP, a socially conservative party from Northern Ireland, has come to an agreement to support the Conservatives on major issues in exchange for an extra £1 billion of government spending in the region.The deal could help May stay in power, if signed. But if no agreement is made, May could be forced to step down as prime minister.Donaldson said the DUP was "hopeful that we can reach an agreement that will bring stability to the United Kingdom."The prime minister's negotiations have come under heavy criticism from Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who called for a "proper national government" and warned May that the public needed to see the government taking care of urgent issues, such as the Grenfell Tower tragedy.May is expected to announce a deal with the DUP later this week. It is unclear if the agreement will satisfy Corbyn and other opposition parties.

A new advocacy program is helping to train pro-democracy activists from the Middle East and North Africa. The program, organized by the National Endowment for Democracy (NED), aims to provide participants with the tools and techniques needed to become successful advocates for civil and political rights in their respective countries.The program offers free, online training courses on a variety of topics, including human rights protection, investigative journalism, campaigns for change, digital media, and more. Participants also have the chance to take part in an annual networking meeting where they can gain insight and knowledge from experts on the region. The NED’s director for the Middle East and North Africa, Dr. Hanin Ahmad, said: “We are honored to provide this training opportunity to pro-democracy activists and increase their understanding of effective advocacy techniques. This program will give participants the opportunity to be heard in their countries and will foster greater cooperation among those working to build stronger democracies in the region.” The training sessions have been praised by participants, who said they felt more equipped to tackle the challenges of advocating for their causes.The NED is dedicated to helping promote freedom and democracy worldwide. Through its advocacy program, it hopes to foster a more open and democratic environment in the Middle East and North Africa region.

The Bush administration says it is not contemplating curtailing the current surge of U.S. forces in Iraq, as it prepares its first report on the surge due this week to an increasingly skeptical Congress. VOA's Al Pessin reports from the Pentagon.Both here and at the White House, officials steered reporters away from a New York Times story that says senior officials are discussing changing the Iraq strategy President Bush announced in January. White House spokesman Tony Snow put it this way."There is no intensifying discussion about reducing troops," said Tony Snow.At the Pentagon, spokesman Bryan Whitman acknowledged that Defense Secretary Robert Gates postponed a trip to Latin America in order to participate in policy meetings on Iraq this week. He said discussions are going on about what he called "the way ahead" in Iraq. And he reported that Secretary Gates participated in a national security team meeting early Monday morning, after meeting with the commander of U.S. forces in the Middle East, Admiral William Fallon.But Whitman also noted that the latest security operation in Iraq is just three weeks old, and began as soon as all the extra forces President Bush ordered to Iraq had arrived."What this department is focused on is implementing the full capabilities that the surge forces are giving the commanders on the ground," said Bryan Whitman.Whitman dismissed comments by a growing number of Republican members of Congress, who have said the new Iraq strategy is not working and needs to be changed."None of those people seem to be our military commanders on the ground," he said.

Some traditional moon cake producers in Hong Kong have recently decided to forgo lavish packaging and opt for more traditional methods of wrapping their treats.Moon cakes are a traditional Chinese dessert often served during the Mid-Autumn Festival, and have been a major part of the celebration for centuries. While the recipes of the cakes have remained largely unchanged, producers have in recent years become more creative with their packaging.However, some Hong Kong producers have recently made the decision to go back to more traditional packaging. These traditional producers believe that over the years, moon cakes have become too commercialized and too focused on luxurious packaging.According to one producer, the Hong Kong government has imposed new restrictions on packaging materials and this may be a contributing factor to the push for more traditional packaging. The producers are also concerned that expensive packaging will increase the cost of moon cakes, which could be a burden to their customers.These producers hope that their decision will help preserve the traditional value of the festival and its beloved treats. Although luxury packaging was once a trend in the industry, moon cake producers in Hong Kong are now moving away from it and seeking to maintain the traditional spirit of the Mid-Autumn Festival.

Iceland Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson announced today that he will temporarily step aside, not resign, from office.Gunnlaugsson had been facing pressure from the public to resign after he was accused of having hidden millions of dollars in an offshore account, in violation of Iceland's anti-corruption laws. However, Gunnlaugsson has denied any wrongdoing and has refused to resign, though he did indicate that he will be temporarily stepping aside as Prime Minister.In a statement released today, Gunnlaugsson said, "I will be temporarily stepping aside in order to give my fellow party members the space to make the decision on who should be leading the government," adding that "Iceland needs a government that people trust."No timeline has been provided for when he might return to office.The crisis in Iceland has been simmering since documents leaked from Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca last month revealed the offshore accounts and assets held by Gunnlaugsson and his wife.In the wake of the revelations, protests have been held across Iceland calling for Gunnlaugsson's resignation. The opposition party, the Bright Future Party, has also called for a vote of no confidence to be held against the Prime Minister.At this time it is unclear what the next step in the political crisis will be, but it is certain that with the Prime Minister temporarily stepping aside, the situation will be closely monitored by the people of Iceland.

The family of Basuki Tjahaya Purnama and his lawyers on Tuesday announced the recently defeated governor of Jakarta better known as "Ahok" had revoked the decision to appeal a two-year sentence for blasphemy handed down by the North Jakarta District Court.Ahok's wife, Veronica Tan, delivered the notice to the court Monday. She did not comment on the decision, which was filed less than an hour after Purnama's legal team filed paperwork for the appeal, according to local media.On Tuesday, she cried as she read a statement written by her husband."I know it's not easy for you to accept this fact, much less me," she said at a news conference, quoting her husband. "But I have learned to forgive and accept all this, for the good of the nation and the state."

The U.S. government on Thursday marked International Women's Day by recognizing 10 women who are fighting for human rights and equality. Presenting this year's International Women of Courage awards, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said championing women's equality is not only the right thing to do, it is the smart thing to do."Improving the lives of women improves the lives of their families, strengthens their communities and does create more opportunities for economic growth and prosperity," she said. "We know that investing in women's employment, health and education levels leads to a greater economic growth across a broad spectrum.?

Warner Bros. CEO Kevin Tsujihara has stepped down from his position following allegations of misconduct.The allegations stemmed from an article in the Hollywood Reporter, which described how Tsujihara had allegedly promised roles to an actress with whom he had a personal relationship. Warner Bros. investigated the claims and found evidence of improper behavior, leading the studio to announce Tsujihara's departure. In a statement, WarnerMedia said: “It is in the best interest of Warner Bros., WarnerMedia and all our employees to ensure a safe and professional workplace. Kevin acknowledges that his mistakes are inconsistent with the company’s leadership expectations and could impact the company’s ability to execute our strategic vision.”Tsujihara had been with the company for 25 years, and was appointed CEO in 2013. He had overseen the development of the studio’s tentpole franchises, such as the “Harry Potter” and “DC” brands, as well as the launch of the streaming service HBO Max. Tsujihara will be replaced by Ann Sarnoff, who is the former president of BBC Studios Americas and who previously served on the board of directors for the Tribeca Film Festival. Sarnoff is now the first female CEO in the history of Warner Bros.“It is a distinct honor to lead one of the most iconic companies in entertainment," said Sarnoff in a statement. "Warner Bros. is home to some of the most beloved franchises and revered storytellers in the world.

The US government has expressed alarm over the annulment of last week's elections in Zanzibar, Tanzania. The chair of the Zanzibar Electoral Commission (ZEC) announced the decision on Sunday, citing “grave irregularities” in voting and a low voter turnout.The US State Department released a statement on Monday, saying that it was “deeply concerned” by the ZEC’s annulment of the elections and urged “all parties to exercise restraint and peacefully pursue a resolution that is consistent with Tanzania’s democratic aspirations and commitments.” The statement noted that the US had joined the international community in sending observers to the election and noted its deep concern that their reports of the ZEC's "failure to address and investigate credible allegations of electoral fraud" had not been addressed.The Zanzibar polls were part of a larger election in Tanzania, where the ruling Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM) party was declared the winner in the presidential race on Thursday. The US had also expressed concern about the presidential vote, saying there was “evidence of intimidation, biased media coverage, and other obstacles to an inclusive and credible process.”The election results in Zanzibar and in the mainland have been contested by the opposition Civic United Front (CUF) party. The CUF has called for the results to be invalidated, and is demanding a new round of elections.The US has urged Tanzania’s government and the opposition to “engage in meaningful dialogue” and to work “toward a credible electoral outcome that is acceptable to all parties.” It also called on the government to fully address opposition allegations of irregularities and to uphold citizens’ rights to assemble peacefully and express their views.

BERLIN - An old-time propeller plane crashed near-vertically at high speed into a Swiss mountain, killing all 20 people on board, police said Sunday. The Junkers Ju-52 plane, operated by the Swiss company Ju-Air, went down Saturday on the Piz Segnas mountain above the Alpine resort of Flims, striking the mountain's western flank about 2,540 meters (8,330 feet) above sea level. The mountainous area in southeastern Switzerland is popular with hikers and skiers and includes a glacier. Police said Sunday they have now determined that all 20 people on board the plane, including its three crew members, died. Eleven men and nine women between the ages of 42 and 84 were killed. Most of the victims were Swiss but they also included a couple and their son from Austria. Photos released by Graubuenden canton (state) police showed the crumpled wreckage of the plane lying on the mountain, with only the upside-down tail more or less intact. Police said they are not aware of any distress call from the aircraft before it crashed. Daniel Knecht of the Swiss Transportation Safety Investigation Board said the plane appears to have hit the ground near-vertically and at high speed.

Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi reportedly fell ill during a news conference in Switzerland on Friday. Suu Kyi, who is in Geneva to attend the United Nations Human Rights Council meeting, was taken ill at around 10am local time while taking questions from reporters in the Swiss city. According to local media reports, the 72-year-old Nobel laureate was visibly unwell during the press conference. She was eventually taken away by her attendants for medical attention and her speech was cut short. While it is yet to be ascertained what caused the health scare, some reports suggested that Suu Kyi was feeling unwell due to exhaustion after her four-day visit to Switzerland. An outspoken critic of the Myanmar military, Suu Kyi is the de facto head of the National League for Democracy (NLD) government. She has been repeatedly jailed by the military-led government for her staunch advocacy of democracy in the country. Suu Kyi has been a frequent visitor to Switzerland and has attended several UN meetings in the past few years. In recognition of her brave struggle for democracy in her homeland, the Swiss government has honoured her with its highest civilian award in 2014.

The government of Rio de Janeiro has announced plans to launch a “stop gap” clean-up of Guanabara Bay, an essential part of the 2016 Olympic Games.Due to health and environmental concerns, the city government has decided to expedite a process of cleaning the bay in preparation for hosting the sailing events during the upcoming Olympics. It is estimated that the plan will cost around 500 million reals (USD200 million), with a reported 250 million reals to be spent on environmental remediation efforts.Guanabara Bay is a massive body of water, second only to the Amazon River in size. Currently, it has suffered from rampant pollution, mostly due to the countless favelas and unregulated industries situated near its shore. The bay is infamous for its floating rubbish and hazardous oil slicks.Rio state's environmental agency Inea said the plan will include the use of chemical floatation agents to remove rubbish, the dredging of sediment and construction of a wastewater treatment facility.The mayor of Rio, Eduardo Paes, acknowledged that the clean-up will not be a complete solution, and that it would require more than one billion reals to fix the problem completely. However, the mayor expressed optimism that hosting the Olympic sailing events will bring increased attention to the plight of Guanabara Bay and motivate authorities to better protect the environment.The government of Rio has already taken steps to discourage polluting industries from operating near the bay, and has established several conservation zones in the region. These efforts will be amplified during the run up to the Olympics, as officials seek to present a “cleaner and greener” version of Rio to the world.

ATHENS - Europe's refugee crisis is posing risks for the Greek economy and the country needs substantial help to deal with the migratory flows, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) said on Thursday."The refugee crisis creates significant problems for the Greek economy and growth," OECD Secretary-General Angel Gurria told reporters after meeting Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras in Athens."Greece needs to receive substantial support to deal with this new challenge. No single country can address this challenge on its own," he said in comments translated into Greek.Gurria projected zero growth for the Greek economy this year and a 1.9 to 2 percent GDP increase in 2017.

South Korea has ended all trade with North Korea as part of its commitment to support United Nations sanctions imposed against the country over its continued nuclear and ballistic missile tests. The South Korean government announced its decision to terminate all economic cooperation with its northern neighbor on Sunday, citing the "recent grave situation on the Korean Peninsula" as the cause for the move. It also said that it will begin immediately implementing UN Security Council resolutions. The move is seen as a stern rebuke of Pyongyang's continued aggression in the region, coming shortly after North Korea launched a powerful intercontinental ballistic missile test earlier this month. In response, South Korea has also agreed to install four additional launchers for the US-made Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) anti-missile system. The decision to cut trade ties between the two nations marks a significant escalation of hostilities, as the two countries had maintained modest economic ties until now.

Thousands of opposition supporters rallied in Taiwan today to protest President Chen Shui-bian's independence-leaning policies which are increasingly provoking China. Protestors are concerned Mr. Chen is spending more time stirring up trouble with China than solving problems at home.Tens of thousands of demonstrators chanted slogans in Taipei Sunday criticizing President Chen Shui-bian recent moves that have antagonized China.In the last several months, Mr. Chen has sparked tensions with Beijing when he suspended a commission responsible for reunification with China. He also scrapped reunification guidelines and proposed amending the constitution to change the island's name from "Republic of China" to "Taiwan."China sees these actions as moving dangerously close to Taiwan formally declaring independence - something Beijing has vowed to stop by force if necessary. While the democratic island has been self-ruled since 1949 - the communist mainland considers it a renegade province.China's opposition Kuomintang organized Sunday's rally, calling on the Chen government to stop provoking China and focus on domestic issues.Kuomintang chairman, Ma Ying-jeou, spoke to crowds of supporters.Ma says there are many problems Taiwan needs to address - including corruption and the economy. He says if Taiwan gets its priorities wrong there will be a huge price to pay.Ma, who is the mayor of Taipei and considered a presidential favorite in Taiwan's 2008 elections, will be in the United States this week.He is to discuss a stalled U.S. weapons sale.

Israeli authorities have approved 200 new homes in a Jewish area of East Jerusalem, a move sure to anger Palestinians as tensions between the two sides continue to grow.A government spokeswoman said officials approved the houses Wednesday for the Ramot area on the northern edge of Jerusalem.There was no immediate comment from Palestinian officials. But U.S. State Department spokeswoman Jen Psaki said the United States was deeply concerned. She said new Jewish settlement construction could worsen a difficult situation and would not contribute to efforts to reduce tensions.Psaki also condemned an arson attack on a mosque in the West Bank on Wednesday, apparently carried out by Israeli extremists. She said hateful actions against a place of worship are never justified.Secretary of State John Kerry plans to meet with Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas during a visit to Jordan on Thursday.Much of the recent violence in Israel has stemmed from the dispute over the Temple Mount, a holy site that Muslims call the al-Aqsa mosque. It is revered by Muslims and Jews.The long-simmering dispute over the site worsened this month when Israeli police shot dead a Palestinian gunman who had seriously wounded a U.S.-born rabbi. The rabbi had been part of a conference on expanding the rights of Jews to worship at the site.Also Wednesday, Israel's foreign ministry said it had no intention of cooperating with a U.N.

A recent report has revealed that being a Member of Parliament (MP) in Africa and Asia is the most dangerous job in the world.The report, which was commissioned by the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (IDEA), showed that threats to political representation are a major problem in many countries around the world.According to the report, countries in Africa and Asia have the highest rates of violence and intimidation against MPs. In total, around a quarter of the world's MPs report threats and violence against them as a result of their political activities.The report also found that while the majority of these incidents are verbal, some MPs have also faced physical attacks, including beatings, abductions, and even death threats.The IDEA report emphasized the need to protect MPs in order to ensure democratic representation and protect human rights. It concluded that governments must do more to investigate and prosecute those responsible for the violence and intimidation of MPs.The report also recommended that governments should adopt protective measures, such as providing better security for MPs, as well as training on protection mechanisms for MPs and their families.It is clear from this report that governments in Africa and Asia must take urgent action to address the issue of violence and intimidation against MPs and ensure democratic representation for all.

Ethiopia's football team has reached the group stage of the 2014 World Cup qualifiers with a comfortable victory over neighboring Somalia. But, for the thousands of Somalis packed into a corner of Addis Ababa stadium, a 5-0 drubbing felt like a victory.As Somalia's fans trooped out of the stands following Wednesday's game, you might have thought they had won. Twenty-five-year-old Mohamed Hussein, a Somali refugee from Mogadishu, was ecstatic.?I'm so happy, I want to thank the players, and I want to thank the people of Somalia today who stay in Addis Ababa who support our team," said Hussein.A valiant Somali side held Ethiopia to a scoreless draw in the first leg of this home and away match, held Saturday in Djibouti. In this return leg in Addis Ababa, the Ocean Stars trailed by only 1-0 at the one hour mark, before the superior Ethiopian side unleashed a torrent of goals.The team for war-torn Somalia faces huge disadvantages in international competition, among them the lack of a home field. Mogadishu Stadium has not been used for sporting events in recent years. Instead, it was used by Islamist militant group al-Shabab for floggings and executions.Somali refugee Hamdi Wardhere called the final score ?great? considering the difficulties his country faces."I'm very delighted how I see my team and how they played, so I'm very happy really," said Wardhere.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman discussed the disappearance of Jamal Khashoggi during a phone call on Wednesday, according to a Turkish presidential source.Khashoggi, a Saudi journalist and critic of the Saudi government, went missing after entering the Saudi consulate in Istanbul earlier this month. His fate remains unknown, although many believe he was killed inside the consulate.The conversation between Erdogan and bin Salman was "frank and sincere", according to the source. Erdogan and bin Salman reportedly agreed to cooperate in the ongoing investigation into Khashoggi's disappearance and to continue discussing the issue.The phone call marked the first official contact between the two countries since Khashoggi vanished. Saudi Arabia has denied any knowledge of his fate and insisted he left the consulate the same day. Turkey, however, maintains that Khashoggi was murdered by a team of Saudi agents, who are said to have targeted him due to his criticism of the kingdom.The disappearance of Khashoggi has triggered a global outcry and placed a spotlight on the kingdom's human rights record. Many international leaders and organizations are now calling for answers from Saudi authorities.

Somalia's interim Prime Minister Ali Mohamed Gedi says his secular government troops and their Ethiopian allies are firmly in control of the capital, Mogadishu, one day after the once-powerful Islamists hastily abandoned the city. VOA Correspondent Alisha Ryu has details from our East Africa Bureau in Nairobi.In a telephone interview with VOA shortly before he entered the capital, Prime Minister Gedi says Somali government troops are now headquartered in the former U.S. Embassy compound in western Mogadishu and assessing the security situation.The interim leader acknowledges that the first priority for his government is to restore stability in the capital. He says he has been given assurances by clan elders in Mogadishu that they would switch support of the Islamists to the interim government and help disarm and re-train hundreds of Islamist militiamen, who found themselves without a job Thursday after the sudden collapse of the Islamist movement."They are ready to hand over weapons to the government and also the militias to be trained in camps. So, this is a victory for the Somali people in the country and in particular, the capital city of Mogadishu," he said.Many Islamist fighters shed their uniforms and sought advice from clan leaders about what to do next.

A leader at one of Virginia's largest mosques has resigned after the imam there made comments in support of female genital mutilation.Imam Johari Abdul-Malik, who was director of outreach at the Dar Al-Hijrah mosque in Falls Church, posted his resignation Friday on his website.Abdul-Malik says he's leaving after "many reprehensible statements" by Dar Al-Hijrah's senior imam, Shaker Elsayed, including his recent comments on genital mutilation.In a recorded lecture, Elsayed described the practice as a way to avoid "hyper-sexuality" and "the honorable thing to do if needed."Dar Al-Hijrah's board denounced Elsayed's comments Monday. Two days later, it placed him on administrative leave.FILE - Imam Shaker Elsayed delivers the sermon at prayers services at the Dar al-Hijra mosque in Falls Church, Va., June 15, 2005.In the lecture, Elsayed says that the practice, also known as female circumcision, has received a bad name because poorly trained surgeons are too aggressive in the procedure. He said the surgery is properly carried out with a minimalist approach "so that she is not hyper-sexually active. This is the purpose."Elsayed later issued a clarification through the mosque's website saying that "Islam would never support anything that harms anybody's well-being" and that he should have avoided his comments on hyper-sexuality."I hereby take it back. And I do apologize to all those who are offended by it," Elsayed wrote.Abdul-Malik says in his resignation that the board's actions against Elsayed are insufficient."Ultimately, The Board of Dar Al-Hijrah Islamic Center is responsible for the direction of the community and its leadership.

North Korea has fired another ballistic missile, days after the United States imposed new sanctions on the reclusive state.South Korea's Joint Chiefs of Staff said the missile flew 800 kilometers before crashing off the North's eastern coast early Friday. The South said it tracked the projectile and was monitoring the situation.A U.S. defense official says the U.S. tracked the launch of two ballistic missiles from North Korea. The official said neither was assessed to be a threat to the U.S. or its allies, and noted that the launches are a violation of multiple U.N. Security Council resolutions.President Barack Obama signed an executive order imposing new sanctions Wednesday in response to the authoritarian regime's latest nuclear and ballistic missile tests.Earlier this week, Pyongyang's state media said North Korean leader Kim Jong Un had ordered tests of a nuclear warhead and ballistic missiles capable of carrying warheads.Military tensions have been soaring on the divided Korean Peninsula since the North carried out its fourth nuclear test on January 6, followed a month later by a long-range rocket launch that was widely seen as a disguised ballistic missile test.The North says it needs nuclear weapons to cope with what it calls U.S. military threats.After the latest firing, the United States called on North Korea to refrain from actions that raise tensions in the region.

New warnings of famine and food shortages have been sounded for parts of the Horn of Africa.The Famine Early Warning Systems Network says more than one-million people in south and southeast Ethiopia face "extreme food insecurity" due to the failure of normal late-year rains.The U.S.-funded group says pre-famine conditions have emerged in several districts, including Afder, Liban and Gode).The group says two million people need humanitarian aid in Somalia, mostly in the south, where the poor rainfall has led to widespread crop failure.

New Zealand police said there were multiple fatalities after a mass shooting at two mosques in Christchurch, a city of about 375,000 located on the nation’s South Island.Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said the shootings have led to “one of New Zealand’s darkest days.”What is the history of Christchurch, New Zealand?The planned settlement of Christchurch was founded in 1850 by a company financed by the Church of England.?4,545,627, as of July 2018, according to the CIA: The World Factbook.The estimated number of guns (both licit and illicit) held by civilians in New Zealand was estimated to be more than 1.2 million in 2017, according to GunPolicy.org.New Zealand has had few mass shooting deaths. One of the deadliest cases involved David Gray who in November 1990 went on a shooting spree in the small town of Aramoana, located about 360 kilometers south of Christchurch.

Senegal's electoral court on Wednesday certified the re-election of 85-year-old incumbent President Abdoulaye Wade, in a vote marred by violence and allegations of fraud.The court ruled that Wade had won with more than 58 percent of the total votes in Sunday's presidential elections, ahead of his main challenger, Macky Sall. The result had been widely expected due to Senegal's longtime ruling party having a firm grip on power.Violence had broken out in Dakar, the nation's capital, ahead of the election as protesters demanded the resignation of Wade. Several people were killed and hundreds more injured in the clashes.The Organization of the Islamic Conference and the African Union had both called for the peaceful resolution of disputes, and for a free and fair vote. Senegal's government subsequently agreed to allow foreign observers for the election.Despite their presence, however, reports of fraud and irregularities were widespread. The opposition has dismissed the results of the election and has called on supporters to take to the streets in protest.The Supreme Court must still ratify Wade's re-election, although it is widely expected to do so without much issue. If approved, it will be Wade's third term in office, having served since 2000.

The United Nations has warned that more than one million children in Burma are at risk of severe health issues, displacement, and exploitation in the aftermath of Cyclone Nargis. The storm, which hit the south of the country on May 2nd, has caused massive destruction and disruption of vital services. The UN's Children's Fund, UNICEF, estimates that more than 300,000 children have been affected by the disaster and more than 1 million are at risk in the coming days and weeks. "The cyclone and its aftermath present an urgent challenge to Burma's government and its international partners," said UNICEF Executive Director Ann Veneman in a statement. "I urge the international community to respond quickly to avert a humanitarian crisis for the millions of children and families in the affected areas."The UN has launched a major aid effort and is calling for an increase in foreign donations. According to reports, the military junta of Burma has delayed the delivery of aid in a move which has been criticized as a breach of basic humanitarian ethics. UNICEF has warned that the long-term effects of the storm could be disastrous for the country's children unless urgent action is taken. UNICEF is particularly concerned about the high levels of malnutrition, lack of access to clean drinking water, and increased vulnerability to disease. "We must ensure that no child is deprived of the basic necessities of life," said Veneman.

The U.S. space agency NASA has released the first three dimensional pictures of the sun. It says the new view will greatly help scientists understand solar storms that can disrupt communications and power systems on Earth. VOA's David McAlary reports.The new 3-D images came from twin NASA spacecraft named STEREO, launched last October. They are orbiting the sun, one slightly ahead of Earth and the other slightly behind, gradually separating from each other until they are 500,000 kilometers apart. The separation provides a three dimensional view of the sun, just as the offset in our eyes gives us depth perception.Until the advent of this identical pair of observatories, images from Earth telescopes or orbiting solar telescopes were two dimensional. NASA solar scientist Madhulika Guhathakurta says the three dimensional images will help scientists determine where matter and energy flow in the sun's atmosphere much more precisely."We have to move away from the traditional sun-Earth line to view the sun from around, from over the poles, from under the poles to really get a deeper understanding of what is inside the sun, what is coming out of its surface, how is it affecting the entire solar system that we live in," said Madhulika Guhathakurta.The main STEREO project scientist, Michael Kaiser, says the satellites' depth perception will help improve space weather forecasts.Of particular concern are powerful eruptions of billions of tons of electrically charged gas that smash into Earth's magnetic field at millions of kilometers per hour.

Getachew Engida spoke in an interview Thursday about his work as deputy director general of the large U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, his views on the growth and development of societies around the world and his career path that lead him to UNESCO.“I wanted to do things that go beyond the financial and other profit goals,” Getachew said, “to explore causes that are not necessarily for profit-making but are good for the betterment of the society." He spoke with Alula Kebede, host of Cultural MosaicThe deputy director previously served for six years as comptroller of the Paris-based agency with oversight of a half-billion dollar annual budget.

WASHINGTON - The United States urged all Venezuelan political parties on Monday to follow up on the country's elections with a dialogue to deal with the country's economic and social challenges, saying Washington is ready to support such an effort.U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry congratulated Venezuelans on Sunday's legislative elections, in which the ruling Socialists lost their majority in the National Asseembly.The United States has long had an acrimonious relationship with Venezuela, which under President Nicolas Maduro and President Hugo Chavez before him has been a vocal critic of Washington.In a written statement, Kerry said the vote showed Venezuelans' "overwhelming desire" for a change in the direction of the country, and urged authorities "to continue to tabulate and publish voting results in a timely and transparent fashion."Sunday's victory for the opposition Democratic Unity coalition punished Maduro's government for deep economic and social crisis in the oil-producing country. It was the first time in 16 years that the "Chavismo" movement, named for former President Chavez, lost its majority in the 167-member assembly."

MANILA - The Philippines is one of the world’s most vulnerable countries when it comes to disasters and weather-related events. And this week it is hosting a three-day intensive seminar to help develop “climate leaders” who will be tasked to call attention to the impacts of climate change and what action can be taken.Climate reality From 1994 to 2013, the Philippines had 328 major weather events making it the worst-off country, according to data presented by former U.S. Vice President Al Gore, now the chairman of the Washington-based Climate Reality Project. Second on the list was Bangladesh, with 228 events.Former U.S. Vice President Al Gore addresses participants during a three-day climate change training and workshop on how best to address the effects of global climate change on March 14, 2016 in suburban Pasay city, south of Manila, Philippines.Gore’s presentation in Manila made the connection between rising earth temperatures, powerful storms, extreme heat, more prolonged drought and their impact on food supplies, public health and political stability.“I am constantly challenged in my own heart to realize the magnitude of these biblical changes that are going on right now,” he said.“ And we are the people alive in this day and time that have a responsibility to recognize it and then to act.”

Philippine troops have killed three communist rebels in the southern part of the country, the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) said on Wednesday. According to the AFP, the incident happened in the early morning of Tuesday in an area known as Lake Sebu in South Cotabato. In a statement, the AFP said the three rebels were killed after they engaged troops in a "firefight."The statement did not identify the slain rebels, who are said to be part of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP). The AFP said they were able to recover firearms and other materials from the rebels after the incident.

Anti-genocide groups have cautiously approved a new strategy announced by former President Barack Obama to address the ongoing conflict in Sudan. The strategy was laid out in a statement by the Obama Foundation which highlighted “the urgent need for the Sudanese people to be given a choice to peacefully transition to a new democratic nation.” It called for Sudan to be unified under a civilian-led transitional government, and for the international community to protect civilians from violence. The new policy has been welcomed by the Enough Project, a US-based group which works to end genocide and crimes against humanity. “The Obama strategy’s emphasis on a civilian-led and fully inclusive transition is a much-needed shift away from the undemocratic and un-inclusive militarily led transition that has been envisioned by the Transitional Military Council,” Enough Project executive director Jonathan Hutson said in a statement.However, Hutson said that a “sustained, aggressive” international effort was needed to ensure the violence in Sudan stops. He called on the United Nations to use its existing powers, such as an arms embargo, to pressure the country into political reform. The Enough Project also warned of the potential for further military violence if “violent spoilers” are not held accountable for human rights abuses. The statement from the Obama Foundation also noted the need for a sustained commitment from the international community to support the political transition in Sudan. It said that this would require “robust multilateral support” and urged world leaders to put pressure on Sudan to make a peaceful transition. The new strategy marks a shift in US policy towards Sudan and is widely seen as a positive step towards ending the country’s decades of conflict. However, many in the international community remain skeptical that a peaceful solution can be reached, and are calling for continued pressure to be placed on the Sudanese government.

Google is taking steps to crack down on "fake news" and offensive search suggestions. In a recent announcement, the company said they will now rely on artificial intelligence (AI) to identify and remove false information from their search results.The technology giant said it would be able to detect when content is intended to mislead or deceive readers, or to misrepresent a situation. The AI will also be able to detect offensive or inappropriate search suggestions, including those that contain profanity or racial slurs.Google said these measures will help reduce confusion and chaos on its search engine, and will help maintain a clean and organized internet for users to access information without interference.Google also said it is investing in tools to detect deceptive or fraudulent websites, and malicious content that appears to be genuine. The company claims this will make it easier for users to find accurate and trustworthy content, and will help combat the spread of false information.The move comes in light of recent criticism over the spread of disinformation and hate speech on the internet. Google has been accused of allowing such content to circulate on its platform, leading to an increase in "fake news" and hate speech.Google's announcement is part of a broader effort to fight misinformation and offensive content on its search engine. The company has also implemented stricter policies and improved moderation systems to better detect and take down inappropriate content.It is clear that Google is taking steps to ensure its search engine is a safe and reliable source of information. With these measures in place, users will have access to a cleaner and more organized online experience.

Hundreds of protesters took to the streets in India's capital on Sunday to voice their outrage over the deaths of sewer cleaners.Demonstrators blocked several major roads as they shouted slogans and carried placards expressing their dismay at the inaction of the authorities in the face of the lives lost due to unsafe working conditions.The protesters also called for immediate reforms in the way manual scavenging is carried out in the country. They demanded better protective gear, training, and a complete ban on the practice.The deaths of sewer cleaners over the past few months have sparked nationwide protests as people raise their voice against the inhuman practice. The protesting voices have been gaining steam as social media platforms have been inundated with calls for the government to do more to protect the rights of these laborers and hold those responsible to account.The current wave of protests have seen ordinary citizens, celebrities, and politicians joining together to express solidarity with the movement. Political leaders from different parties have stated their commitment to protect the rights of these vulnerable workers and to take urgent steps to prevent any more lives being lost.The protests come after several months of deaths due to inhalation of toxic gases while cleaning sewers, and the need for reform has become increasingly urgent. Despite ongoing efforts from civil society and activists, manual scavenging has been an issue in the country for decades, with the practice being illegal since 1993.The protests in the capital were peaceful, and the police have not reported any incidents of violence.

The White House is reportedly looking into a policy to send migrants who have crossed the US-Mexico border illegally to sanctuary cities.The controversial policy, which would have migrants moved from areas where illegal crossings are frequent and moved to locations with cities that provide protection to undocumented immigrants, was first reported by the Washington Post on Thursday.The Trump administration has not yet confirmed the plans, but White House officials are said to have discussed the idea at several meetings. However, the idea has apparently been rejected by both the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and Health and Human Services (HHS) for now due to logistical and legal concerns.“This was just a suggestion that was floated and rejected, which ended any further discussion,” a White House official said.Sanctuary cities are those that have adopted policies that limit local authorities from cooperating with federal immigration enforcement. There are currently over 200 sanctuary cities across the US.The plan is likely to face strong opposition from Democrats, who have criticized the Trump administration’s immigration policies as too hard-line. It is unclear how much public support the plan has, as many Republican lawmakers have yet to comment.

The Pentagon says an Iranian operative captured in Iraq on Thursday and accused of helping Iraqi insurgents was acting under orders from the elite Quds Force. VOA's Al Pessin reports from the Pentagon.The U.S. military command in Iraq says the man was arrested in Sulimaniyah Province in the northeast along the Iranian border. The command says the unidentified man is an officer of the Quds Force, an elite unit of Iran's Revolutionary Guards Corps. It says he was involved in transporting special, high-technology roadside bombs that have the power to pierce the armor of U.S. military vehicles. A U.S. military statement says there are indications from intelligence agencies that the man was also involved in training foreign fighters and smuggling them into Iraq.About six other alleged Quds force members have been detained in Iraq on similar charges, but U.S. officials have said they are not sure whether the men are operating under orders from the highest levels of the Iranian government.Still, Pentagon Press Secretary Geoff Morrell said Thursday it appears this latest detainee was not operating on his own."The Quds Force is a tightly controlled paramilitary force for the government of Iran," he said. "So I think it seems to us as though, indeed, he's not operating as a Lone Ranger in Iraq, but he has been presumably ordered to be there."

A typical math problem for an American middle school student might be to calculate the sales tax on a dozen baseball caps. At an after-school program called the Berkeley Math Circle, a typical problem is more? advanced. As she writes the hyperbolic cosine formula on the blackboard, circle director Zvezda Stankova asks the four dozen or so teens in the room to use it in a differential equation to describe the arc of a wire, hanging between two poles.It's no problem for 12-year-old Bobby Veres, who says Math Circle teens can handle this. He points out, "It's very prestigious. Most of the top math kids from around the Bay area come here. I like the chance that we get to learn extra math that isn't available in schools, and we get to make friends."They also get to hear from some top mathematicians and theorists, like astrophysicist Cliff Stoll. Stankova calls him the epitome of what you would think of an internationally renown scientist: "Absent-minded, yet very animated. Very sharp and very enthusiastic." And very demonstrative. Stoll is jumping high, spreading his arms wide, then running forward until he's nose to nose with the Math Circle students - all this to show the three dimensions of our universe: height, width and depth. With Stoll in command, the Math Circle takes a wild ride from our 3-D universe to an imaginary world of two dimensions, that's limited to only width and height. "Can I tie a knot in a string that's in a two-dimensional universe?" he asks, prompting a chorus of "No!" When one student says "yes," Stoll challenges him to prove it.

A privately owned spacecraft launched from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Friday and is headed to the International Space Station (ISS).The spacecraft, which is owned by Axiom Space and Space Exploration Technologies Corp. (SpaceX), is scheduled to reach the ISS on Sunday. It will be carrying four astronauts aboard the Crew Dragon capsule. The launch is significant as it marks the first time a private spacecraft has gone to the ISS. This opens the door for private companies to send astronauts to low-Earth orbit for various research purposes.The astronauts who are on the spacecraft have been preparing for weeks and have been training on the emergency systems, practice spacewalks and spacecraft operations.NASA and SpaceX are both excited for this mission and hope that it will pave the way for further exploration and scientific discovery.This mission is a huge step forward for both private and public space exploration and is sure to draw much attention and admiration.

Nepalese police have arrested at least 50 journalists after scuffling with them during a protest against media restrictions imposed by the royal government.The members of the Federation of Nepalese Journalists were arrested as they marched into a restricted area near the royal palace.They were demanding an immediate restoration of press freedom and an end to harassment and arrests by security forces.Police bundled the journalists into buses and drove them away.Journalists have held several protests since February first, when King Gyanendra seized absolute power. The government arrested 53 journalists during a similar protest last Wednesday, but released them a day later.Last week, the Vienna-based International Press Institute told the king in a statement that "the best antidote to the present situation in the country is more speech and greater discussion."Some information for this report provided by AP and AFP.

SANTIAGO - Taxi drivers in Chile protested on Thursday against ride-hailing app Uber, as authorities indicated they were considering more regulatory oversight to deal with car-sharing services.Blocking an avenue in downtown Santiago, the taxi drivers' demonstration was the latest in a series around the globe against the service, which critics say is unsafe, skirts labor laws and depresses wages."I don't have a problem that they work - we all have a right to earn money - but this has reduced our business a lot," said taxi driver Jaime Poblete Soto, 30. "The [drop in customers] has become very obvious."On Wednesday, a similar anti-Uber protest took place in the Argentine city of Cordoba, and in late March four men torched an Uber vehicle in Nairobi, Kenya.Massive Uber protests have also taken place in recent months in Brazil, Mexico, France and several other nations.Taxi drivers in France and other countries have been protesting Uber's operations and calling for them to be suspended, Paris, Jan. 26, 2016.Uber Chile, which started in December 2014 and now has around 10,000 registered drivers, according to the company, has repeatedly called on national authorities to establish a clearer regulatory framework for ride-sharing apps.As of now, the company said, drivers operate in a legal gray zone."What we do isn't covered by current law, so we've asked for help in trying to find a way to regulate this, but we've been told 'no,'" said Carlos Schaaf, chief executive of Uber Chile."

A prominent union leader in Kenya has harshly criticized the sacking of hundreds of healthcare workers due to a financial dispute between the government and medical services providers.Joseph Mutuku, the head of the Kenya National Union of Workers, called the sacking of the healthcare workers a "slap in the face" of medical professionals in the country.The dispute began after the Kenyan government failed to pay medical providers for services they provided to clients who are insured by the state health system. As a result, many of the healthcare providers were forced to lay off hundreds of employees.Mutuku claims the move is a reflection of a larger issue of financial mismanagement by the government. He also blamed the government for failing to take responsibility for the problem and taking punitive action instead of addressing the root cause.The sacking of healthcare workers has raised serious concerns about the quality and availability of healthcare in the country. Mutuku urged the government to resolve the issue quickly to prevent further disruptions to the health system. He also called on them to treat healthcare workers fairly and ensure their financial well-being.

Taiwan has expressed an interest in playing a role in the resolution of an ongoing island dispute in the South China Sea. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi declared on Tuesday that the Chinese government had offered to mediate in the dispute, which involves the islands of Spratly and Paracel.Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen also called for a peaceful solution to the territorial dispute, expressing a willingness to act as a peacekeeper. She argued that Taiwan's close proximity to the two disputed island chains gives it the unique ability to play a crucial part in the resolution of the issue.The Taiwanese government has made its position clear: it does not support any claim that is contrary to international law or sovereignty, and it is committed to preserving the status quo in the region. Tsai Ing-wen has also called for cooperation between all parties involved in the dispute, stressing the need for all countries to find a peaceful solution to the problem.At a press conference, Foreign Minister Wang Yi reiterated that China will continue to play an active role in the peace process. He also noted that, although Taiwan is not officially part of China, its "mainland" neighbor was open to dialogue and willing to facilitate a resolution to the island dispute.Taiwan's plea for peace and its expressed willingness to act as a mediator reflect the country's desire to be taken seriously as a regional player. Whether it will be allowed to take part in the negotiations remains to be seen.

Violent crime in the United States fell in the first half of 2017, according to a preliminary report released Tuesday by the FBI, but the number of homicides rose in the same period.Property crimes declined by nearly three full percentage points over the same period.For the first six months of 2017, overall violent crime decreased 0.8 percentage point compared with the same time period in 2016. In comparison, the nationwide violent crime rate increased by nearly 7 percent during 2015 and 2016.Rates of violent crime in cities with more than a million residents fell by 3.3 percentage points. Property crime rates fell most in smaller cities with populations below 50,000.Also during the first half of 2017, rapes decreased 2.4 percentage points; robberies decreased 2.2 percentage points; and aggravated assaults were down 0.1 percentage point. All three categories increased during the same period in 2016.In an op-ed piece published by USA Today on Tuesday, Attorney General Jeff Sessions said the statistics proved that President Donald Trump has kept a promise he made at his inauguration to end "This American carnage."

The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) aims to boost investments in Arab countries to 2.5 billion euros ($2.92 billion) at the end of 2018 from 2.2 billion in 2017, a senior official said Tuesday.The bank, set up by governments in 1991 to support the ex-Communist states of eastern Europe, has expanded its mandate in the past few years to invest in Jordan, Tunisia, Morocco and Egypt."Last year we had a record 2.2 billion euros invested in Morocco, Tunisia, Egypt and Jordan," said Janet Heckman, managing director for the southern and eastern Mediterranean region at the bank."

Today, Voice of America (VOA) announced its new radio show Daybreak Africa, a new morning program airing on VOA's English language service and dedicated to providing African news and stories.Daybreak Africa will offer stories on African current events, culture, health, and politics, exploring complex issues in an engaging and informative manner.

Four young men who recently graduated from high school have become radio broadcasters in Haromaya district of eastern Hararghe. Jamal Asee, Usmael Alisho, Zahir Usman and Zakir Abdul-Karim started experimenting in 2002 in an effort to create a mobile phone. They dismantled their radio sets, reassembled and reconnected the parts of the radios on a large hardboard to make a transmitter with enough power to relay broadcasts to a 36-kilometer range.

John Kerry, the US Secretary of State, expressed outrage over the latest Syrian airstrike on a children's hospital in Aleppo on Wednesday.The hospital, located in the besieged city of Aleppo, was hit by air strikes, killing seven people and leaving several dozen injured. Kerry said it was a "morally reprehensible and completely unacceptable" attack on innocent civilians."This most recent attack is an outrageous violation of international law and a moral outrage," Kerry said.The United Nations has expressed deep concern over the situation in Aleppo, with the UN Secretary General calling for an immediate end to the fighting. The attack on the children's hospital has added to the already dire humanitarian situation in the city. Kerry said the US was continuing to use its diplomatic channels to pressure the Syrian government to end its military campaign. He added that the US is also considering a range of options to put an end to the ongoing violence in Syria. The Syrian government has so far not commented on the airstrike, but has maintained that it is targeting only "terrorists". However, many independent observers have accused the government of indiscriminate bombing of civilian areas in its fight against rebel forces.

North Korea recently conducted a missile launch test that failed almost immediately after being fired. This has caused some concern amongst military and international experts, despite the fact that the test launch was unsuccessful.Experts note that North Korea's technological progress is still being monitored carefully, despite the failure of the test launch. According to a statement from the Pentagon, the test launch began at 3:30am local time on Sunday, April 16, and the missile went off course within two minutes of launch.South Korea has expressed its disappointment with North Korea's actions and called the missile launch a "provocative act". The United States has also condemned North Korea's actions and called for the regime to adhere to UN Security Council resolutions.Other international organizations, such as the EU and NATO, have also expressed their displeasure at North Korea's missile launch. They have urged North Korea to take steps to halt its pursuit of nuclear weapons and missile development.While North Korea has made some progress in developing a nuclear weapon, it is still far from possessing the technology to make an intercontinental ballistic missile. In the meantime, experts remain concerned that North Korea's missile tests could destabilize the region, even if it fails to produce a viable weapon.

The U.S. financial crisis continued to dominate the presidential campaign Friday, as both major party candidates for the White House spoke about what they would do to deal with the market turmoil. VOA National correspondent Jim Malone has more from Washington. Republican candidate John McCain spoke in Wisconsin and said the U.S. central bank should stop bailing out failed financial institutions, and should return to the main job of managing the money supply and guarding against inflation.McCain said that, if elected president, he would set up a Mortgage and Financial Institutions Trust, MFI for short, which he says would help homeowners avoid foreclosure."The MFI will restore investor and market confidence, build sound financial institutions, assist troubled institutions and protect our financial system, while minimizing taxpayer exposure," he said.McCain also ramped up the attacks on his Democratic opponent, Senator Barack Obama. McCain said Obama's ties to the failed mortgage lenders Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae, including campaign contributions, make him part of the problem."We've heard a lot of words from Senator Obama over the course of this campaign," he said. "But maybe, just this once, he could spare us the lectures, and admit to his own poor judgment in contributing to these problems."

US Olympians have expressed concerns about the safety of the food they are expected to consume while attending the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, China. With the Games set to take place in February next year, athletes are worried about what they will be eating, citing numerous food safety issues in the country.American Olympic skiier Lindsey Vonn was among those to voice her concerns, saying in a recent interview: "I think the biggest thing for me would be to figure out what I'm eating and make sure that it is safe. I'm nervous."Similar worries have been expressed by other American athletes, such as snowboarder Chloe Kim, who told The Associated Press: "I'm a little nervous just with the whole food thing, I know that's always been a little dicey over there."Food safety is a serious issue in China, where food products have been known to contain dangerous levels of heavy metals and banned additives. The Chinese government has made efforts to address the issue, introducing new regulations in 2013, but many citizens remain worried.China's foreign ministry responded to the concerns expressed by US athletes, saying that all relevant measures have been taken to ensure the safety and quality of all the food provided to Olympic athletes and staff.The 2022 Winter Olympics will be the first time China has hosted the Games, and the country has stated its intent to make it one of the best yet. However, American athletes have yet to be convinced and are anxiously awaiting the event, while closely monitoring what they will be putting in their mouths.

Spanish authorities have rescued 440 migrants in the Mediterranean Sea on Sunday, marking a new crackdown on rescue boats operating in the region.The Spanish coast guard stated that a total of 16 boats carrying migrants had been intercepted and the rescued were taken to ports in Malaga, Almeria and Valencia on the mainland. It was reported that three vessels had been turned back from the Spanish shore.The latest rescue operation comes amid increased tensions in the Mediterranean after Italy and Malta, two of the biggest search-and-rescue hubs, closed their ports to migrant rescue boats last month. Italy has also announced its intention to criminalize NGO's involved in search-and-rescue operations in the Mediterranean.The Spanish authorities have come under immense pressure to protect those attempting to cross the sea, and it appears that they are continuing to take measures to ensure the safety of those in need. Despite the rescue mission on Sunday, migrant rights activists have said that hundreds of people are still in need of aid and have not been able to receive assistance from the government. Sunday's rescue operation serves as a reminder of the ongoing humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean Sea, where thousands of migrants and refugees continue to brave the dangerous journey in search of a better future.

Just hours after top U.S. national security leaders made a rare joint appearance in the White House briefing room Thursday to express concern about efforts by Russia and potentially others to meddle in upcoming U.S. elections, U.S. President Donald Trump made an appearance at a rally where he seemed to be unable to come down hard on Russian President Vladimir Putin, even in the face of the mounting evidence of Russian election interference."I got along great with Putin," Trump said at the rally.Trump again accused the media of writing fake news, calling media reports of Russian interference in U.S. elections a hoax.The president’s rally remarks conflicted with the statements the national security leaders made earlier in the day.WATCH: US National Security Team Concerned About Efforts to Meddle in 2018 Election"We continue to see a pervasive message campaign by Russia to try to weaken and divide the United States," said the director of national intelligence, Dan Coats, adding that he is aware "Russia is not the only country that has an interest in trying to influence our domestic political environment."Coats said President Trump "has specifically directed us to make the matter of election meddling and securing our election process a top priority."FBI Director Christopher Wray, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and Army General Paul Nakasone, who is head of the National Security Agency, also appeared at Thursday's briefing.As they spoke, a letter national security adviser John Bolton sent to five senators of the opposition Democratic Party was released outlining the Trump administration's "extensive, historic actions" taken to "ensure the integrity of our elections and defend against foreign malign influence."

Chile has declared its worst-ever drought as a permanent feature of the country’s climate, and unveiled a plan to tackle the water scarcity crisis.The announcement came at the start of a two-day water forum, where President Michelle Bachelet said Chile needs to move away from its “classic mentality” of only considering the availability of water in times of emergency.“We cannot limit ourselves to go back to the ‘status quo’ of the past or the ways of responding that were used for emergency situations,” Bachelet said.The proposed plan involves a range of initiatives, including strengthening regulations on water resources and management, building the capacity of the public and private sectors in the use of water, and the transfer of funds from the central government to those areas most affected by the water crisis.The country is also preparing for the impacts of climate change, which have exacerbated existing water scarcity issues.“Climate change means that some of these changes that we are seeing in the use of water in Chile are probably going to be with us for the rest of our lives,” Environment Minister Pablo Badenier said.The Chilean government is reportedly looking to provide long-term financing options to help municipalities and communities facing extreme water shortages.“

MR. MORALES: The Iraq war began a little more than a month ago. The "shock and awe" campaign started on March 20th with allied air strikes against leadership targets as US and British forces rolled across the border from Kuwait.On April 5th, American heavy armor penetrated Baghdad. And today, what fighting remains is largely mopping-up pockets of resistance as the U-S leads the post-war reconstruction of Iraq.How was the war won so quickly? And what are the lessons to be learned?Joining me to examine the Iraq war are: military strategist, retired US Army Lieutenant Colonel Ralph Peters; and military historian Victor Davis Hanson of California State University in Fresno, Califronia.Victor Hanson, let me begin with you. In your view, what was the key factor in the coalition victory in Iraq?MR. HANSON: I think it was the ability to start the ground war almost simultaneously with the air war that gave some tactical surprise, when it was hard to achieve surprise because of the past record in Afghanistan and Kosovo, where we didn't use sizeable numbers of ground troops. It saved the infrastructure. It undermined the Iraqi command-and-control. And it gave some powerful messages that we still could act without our allies, such as Turkey or Saudi Arabia. We sort of envisioned the Iraqis -- the Baathists -- as a snake of sorts that was coiled around the Tigris and Euphrates Valley, and rather than just hacking at the coils, we went straight to Baghdad and tried to decapitate it.MR. MORALES: Ralph Peters, let me put that same question to you.MR. PETERS: I certainly agree with everything that has just been said as far as the operational factors go, but I think there is something even beyond that. This really was a civilizational victory.

Aid efforts are ramping up in the Bahamas after the devastation caused by Hurricane Dorian. The Category 5 storm hit the island nation with wind gusts of 185 mph and storm surges as high as 23 feet. The Bahamas Ministry of Tourism estimates that around 13,000 homes have been destroyed or severely damaged, leaving tens of thousands of people homeless.A state of emergency was declared in Grand Bahama and the Abaco Islands as Dorian moved slowly across the country, bringing life-threatening winds and torrential rain for two days. The death toll from the storm now stands at 50 and is expected to rise further.United Nations World Food Programme is airlifting emergency food and supplies to the most affected areas, while the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF) is providing thousands of hygiene kits.The US military and several international aid groups including the International Red Cross have deployed personnel and resources to the region.A crowdfunding campaign in the United States has raised over $9 million for aid efforts, with several celebrities including Khloe Kardashian, Rihanna, and Leonardo DiCaprio donating to the cause.In a recent press conference, Prime Minister of the Bahamas Hubert Minnis said, “We are in the midst of one of the greatest national crises in our country’s history. The devastation is unprecedented and extensive.”The government of the Bahamas has issued an international appeal for help, asking the international community for assistance in the form of cash donations and in-kind supplies. The official death toll is expected to increase in the days to come as more areas are searched. The full impact of the storm is still not known, and authorities are urging caution as the clean-up and relief efforts continue.

ISLAMABAD - Pakistan says it is “sincerely” making efforts to reach a negotiated end to the conflict in Afghanistan because doing so would address Islamabad’s own security concerns and encourage millions of Afghan refugees and migrants who have lived in Pakistan for decades to return to their country.National Security Adviser Nasir Janjua made the remarks Tuesday, a day before senior Afghan, Pakistani, Chinese and American diplomats are scheduled to meet in Islamabad to explore ways to start peace talks between the Kabul government and the Taliban.It will be the fifth meeting this year for the parties, known as the Quadrilateral Coordination Group, or QCG.The four-nation group earlier finalized a road map to peace but has not persuaded the Taliban to join talks with the Afghan government.Deep differences remain between Kabul and Islamabad on how to push the Taliban to the negotiating table.“These are trying times, challenging times. We are passing through it together. We have some differences, differences in our outlook. We are very sincerely trying to help out [in] the reconciliation. We are trying to play our role in bringing peace to Afghanistan and also to our restive areas. I am sure together we have a shared future,” Janjua said.The lack of progress on peace talks plus increased Taliban attacks are fueling tensions between Afghanistan and Pakistan, where insurgent commanders are allegedly sheltering.Waiting for a decisionAfghan President Ashraf Ghani repeated his demand last week that the time has come for Islamabad to deliver on its commitments.“All four (QCG) states committed to a road map and their obligations, particularly by the state of Pakistan. Those obligations are that if Taliban groups prove irreconcilable then there will be use of force.

Former President Barack Obama is reported to be suffering from a sore throat that may have been caused by acid reflux. The source of his condition is being investigated.Obama’s team has not released any information about his health condition. However, a source close to the family has told reporters that his symptoms point to a possible acid reflux issue. Acid reflux is a condition that occurs when acidic stomach juices rise up into the esophagus, causing a burning sensation in the throat.The former president has long been known for his deep, raspy voice, so this condition could affect his speech. While acid reflux can be treated with medication and lifestyle changes, it can also have more serious implications if left untreated.At this time, Obama is reported to be doing well and is in good spirits. He is currently focused on his work on civil rights and social justice. He is also actively fundraising for Joe Biden’s 2020 presidential campaign.

Eritrea has invited Sudan's President Omar al-Bashir to make an official visit, in defiance of an international court's move to arrest Sudan's president for alleged crimes against humanity.Eritrea's foreign minister, Osman Saleh, delivered the invitation from President Isaias Afewerki to Bashir during a meeting in the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, on Tuesday. Eritrea's information minister, Ali Abdu, told the Tigrigna and Amharic services that Bashir has accepted the invitation, but that a date for the visit has not been set. Ali Abdu said, "the ICC allegation violates Sudanese sovereignty and territorial integrity, and hence it is unjustified, and unacceptable and totally unwarranted." He said, "External politics would not solve Sudanese problem, but comprehensive and lasting solution on the basis of Sudan-Sudan approach."The International Criminal Court issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Bashir last week.
