TAIPEI - A tiny group of islands in the East China Sea has shaped up as a flashpoint between Beijing and Tokyo. But smaller and diplomatically isolated Taiwan also claims the disputed Senkaku archipelago, which it calls the Diaoyutai. In Taipei, authorities have shied away from confrontation, while seeking to play a larger role in resolving the conflict. On Tuesday, Taiwanese officials urged Japan and China to back down from a conflict about the Senkaku islets, some 220 kilometers from Taiwan.Taiwan wants Japan to resume talks, after 16 earlier rounds, on fishing rights in waters near the uninhabited islets. Taiwan also asked the other claimants to consider Taiwanese President Ma Ying-jeou’s proposal for setting aside their territorial disputes to explore jointly for resources. Foreign Minister Timothy Yang told a news conference in Taipei that he is worried that the conflict will spiral. He says it is easy to escalate a conflict and harder to make peace. But Yang calls Taiwan a peacemaker for the international community and says that, in face of the East China Sea developments, the president has formulated a peace initiative. He adds that Ma is urging all sides to restrain themselves, set aside disputes, solve conflicts in a peaceful way and develop East China Sea resources together. The minister’s words reflect what analysts call the government’s underlying motives for seeking a broader role in the dispute. When President Ma took office in 2008, he said that despite diplomatic isolation Taiwan would try for more informal participation in international affairs.

Thousands of Parisians frustrated by continuous traffic jams and horrible commuting problems marched through the French capital Sunday, demanding an end to a nationwide rail workers' strike now entering its sixth day Monday.Many of the demonstrators said subway and commuter-train workers should return to work because they already enjoy privileges held by only a few other workers in France.Rail unions told their members to stay off the job today, but agreed to hold talks with managers of the state-run rail company on Wednesday.

South African President Cyril Ramaphosa is coming under fire from the opposition party regarding his handling of the nation’s struggling economy. In response, Ramaphosa is looking to introduce a jobs plan to provide a much needed boost to the labor market.The South African government’s official unemployment rate sits at 29%, making it one of the highest in the world. Ramaphosa has proposed the introduction of a jobs plan that would focus on job creation through increased investment in infrastructure and public works programs. The plan is designed to be implemented over the next five years, with the goal of reducing unemployment and increasing economic growth.In addition to the jobs plan, the South African government is also looking to stimulate the economy through a recently announced stimulus package of over $100 billion. This package includes tax cuts and financial relief for businesses.Ramaphosa and his government face an uphill battle in trying to revive the nation’s economy. However, the President remains confident that with the right combination of fiscal policies and job creation programs, South Africa can turn its current economic slump into an opportunity for economic growth and social development.

Google has announced it will suspend all advertising related to the upcoming referendum on abortion in Ireland. This decision was taken in an effort to protect against potential voter manipulation.The referendum, which will take place on May 25th, will decide whether or not the country's current abortion laws should be amended. Those campaigning for a ‘yes’ vote want to overturn the current 8th amendment which requires doctors to perform abortions only in cases when the mother’s life is at risk.Google said it will implement a “limited political ad policy” in the country until after the vote. All ads related to the referendum will be banned, regardless of which side they are promoting."We have long-standing ads policies which do not allow ads that constitute a political advertisement and we will be putting in place a short-term measure to remind advertisers of that," a Google spokesperson said.The move follows reports of a surge in online ads and other campaigns urging Irish voters to approve a ‘yes’ vote. It has also been noted that Facebook had already banned foreign-funded ads in the country related to the referendum.The Irish government has expressed its support for Google's decision, citing concerns of outside interference in the vote. Prime Minister Leo Varadkar called Google's policy "a very welcome decision." The referendum will have major implications for the future of the country and will likely set the tone for the right to abortion laws in other parts of the world. Regardless of which way the vote swings, it will be up to Google to ensure that the outcome of the referendum is not the result of any manipulation.

The U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said Thursday that the number of sexual harassment complaints workers filed with the agency over the past year rose for the first time in nearly a decade. It attributed the increase to the #MeToo movement.The commission said the number of complaints, known as charges, filed in the fiscal year that ended Sept. 30 rose more than 12 percent over the previous year, when it received about 6,700. It said the numbers were preliminary, as the agency typically publishes comprehensive data from its fiscal year by the following February.EEOC Acting Chair Victoria Lipnic said in a statement that the numbers reflected "the heightened demand of the #MeToo movement."The #MeToo movement emerged in response to accusations of sexual harassment and abuse by powerful men in the entertainment industry starting last October. Many lawyers and other experts had predicted that the movement would spur an uptick in harassment claims.The number of sexual harassment charges lodged with the EEOC had fallen each year since 2010, when nearly 8,000 were filed.Many worker advocates and women's rights groups, as well as the commission in a 2016 report, said the decline was most likely the result of victims' decisions not to report harassment, rather than employers' efforts to effectively address it.In order to sue employers for harassment, workers must first file charges with the EEOC, which enforces federal laws banning workplace discrimination based on sex and other factors.

MANILA, PHILIPPINES - Filipino fans remembering boxing legend Muhammad Ali gathered near the site of his epic "Thrilla in Manila" fight with Joe Frazier for an art and photo tribute Friday.The display near Araneta Coliseum at Ali Mall was launched hours before Ali's burial in the United States. Ali died June 3 at age 74.Outside the coliseum, a cutout picture of Ali stands in a boxing ring. Fans crowded around a screen playing videos of the 1975 match that put the Philippines on the map. At the mall, memorabilia including boxing gloves with Ali's autograph, an original souvenir program and a gold commemorative coin also are on display.The Oct. 1, 1975, heavyweight championship, one of the greatest boxing matches in history, was won by Ali on a technical knockout at the jam-packed coliseum in Manila's suburban Quezon city and was watched by a worldwide audience.Filipino fans look at the memorabilia of the Oct. 1, 1975 "Thrilla in Manila" World Heavyweight boxing fight between Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier at the launch of an exhibit at The Ali Mall in suburban Quezon city northeast of Manila, Philippines Friday, June 10, 2016.Some facts about the fight:— It was the third fight between Ali and Frazier, his most bitter rival. The boxers had split the first two bouts, neither of which compared to the grueling rubber match.

Tensions between Ethiopia and Eritrea have been heightened due to a recent military buildup along their border. The buildup is just one of many sources of tension in a long-running dispute that has been ongoing since 2007.In 2007, both countries signed a peace agreement in an attempt to resolve their differences. Unfortunately, the agreement has not been successful in achieving a lasting solution and tensions have continued to rise in the region.Recently, there has been an increase in military presence in both countries, with both governments deploying troops to the border. This has caused tensions to skyrocket, leading to fears of a potential conflict.In response, international organizations have called for a de-escalation of the situation. The United Nations, African Union, and others have urged both sides to withdraw their troops and work towards a peaceful solution.The continued tensions along the Ethiopia-Eritrea border are a reminder of the need for an effective resolution to the long-running dispute between the two countries. In the absence of a lasting peace agreement, further escalation of the situation could be extremely dangerous.

The US economy is experiencing an unexpected level of growth, according to a report released today by the US Department of Commerce. According to the report, the US economy has experienced a 3.3% expansion over the past three months, much higher than the expected 2.8% growth. This is the largest expansion rate for the US economy since the fourth quarter of 2018.The report also showed that consumer spending has been largely responsible for the economic expansion, with consumer spending rising by 3.6% from January to March of this year, up from 2.9% in the last quarter of 2018.The report also noted that businesses have been increasing their spending, leading to an increase in capital investment by 1.7%, up from 0.9%.The report also found that US unemployment remains low, falling to 3.8% in March, down from 3.9% in February.The strong economic expansion has been welcomed by many, with President Trump praising the expansion in a statement released earlier today. "Our economy is going from strength to strength and this report is further evidence of this," President Trump said.

CHARLOTTE, N.C. - A North Carolina college student slain while confronting a gunman in his classroom was expected to receive a hero's send-off Thursday as his body is taken back to his hometown with a police escort.Riley Howell's body was scheduled to depart from a Charlotte funeral home Thursday morning en route to Waynesville in the western part of the state.Meanwhile, the suspect accused of killing Howell and another student at the University of North Carolina-Charlotte, while wounding four others, was due to appear in the afternoon to face charges including murder and attempted murder.Howell died in his classroom Tuesday, charging and tackling the suspect who opened fire with a legally obtained pistol, authorities said.Howell's decision to fight for the lives of others fit his character, said his friend David Belnap, who attended a candlelight vigil Wednesday with a homemade T-shirt with “Riley Howell is a hero” written on the back.“It seems very much like something he would do. I want that to be his legacy, that he lost his life to protect those he cared about,” the sophomore said about his friend.Howell, 21, likely went through the same active shooter drills as countless other students of his generation.

A top United Nations official says drug traffickers are using a more sophisticated system to smuggle drugs from West Africa to Europe.Alexander Schmidt, the West African head of the U.N. Office on Drug Crime, says the amount of cocaine seized in western Africa has gone down, suggesting that smugglers are repositioning drug routes and becoming increasingly sophisticated at hiding their operations.Schmidt says officials also believe cartels are using lightweight submarines similar to ones seen off the South American and the Caribbean coasts.Schmidt says although a few Latin Americans still dominate the trade, West Africans are starting to have increasingly influential roles.He places the value of the drugs passing through West Africa at $800 million.Schmidt spoke Monday at a meeting of the policy committee of the West Africa Coast Initiative.

Turkey is pushing forward with its efforts to revive its stalled bid for membership to the European Union (EU). The government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has pledged to undertake a number of reforms in order to meet the requirements of the EU and to make the country a full-fledged member of the bloc.The bid has been on the backburner since 2005, when the EU began accession negotiations with Turkey, the only majority-Muslim country that is not an EU member. However, negotiations were stalled in 2016 due to disagreements over issues such as human rights, rule of law, and Turkey's ties to countries like Russia and Iran.In an effort to address the issue, the Turkish government has indicated that it will re-open accession talks with the EU and undertake a number of reforms to meet the requirements of the bloc. These reforms include reducing the powers of the military, as well as improving the country’s human rights record.In addition, the government has also vowed to make progress in its relations with its neighbors, which has become increasingly strained in recent years. It has also promised to improve its economy, which is one of the main criticisms of the bid.Despite these promises, Turkey's EU bid remains an uphill battle. The country has been heavily criticized by the bloc for its lack of progress in key areas, and European leaders have become increasingly wary of Turkey’s increasingly authoritarian leanings.Nevertheless, Turkey remains hopeful that its efforts will pay off, and that it will one day become a full member of the European Union.

SANTIAGO - The Chilean public prosecutor's office has summoned the archbishop of Santiago to testify in an investigation into the alleged cover-up of child sexual abuse by members of the Catholic Church, the archbishopric said on Tuesday. The Santiago archbishopric said in a statement that Ricardo Ezzati had been summoned to speak with prosecutors on August 21 as a defendant accused of concealment. Prosecutors investigating criminal accusations against bishops, clerics and lay workers in the Roman Catholic Church in Chile are also probing claims that Ezzati and others covered up a network of 14 priests who systematically abused minors. Ezzati denied wrongdoing and vowed to cooperate with authorities. "I reiterate my commitment and the commitment of Santiago's Church to the victims," Ezzati said in the statement by his office. "I have the conviction that I never covered up or obstructed justice, and as a citizen will fulfill my duty to contribute all the information that may help clarify the facts." Last month police seized documents from the ecclesiastical court of the diocese of Santiago. The child sex abuse crisis has gripped Chile's Catholic Church since 2011, when Chilean priest Fernando Karadima was found guilty by the Vatican of abusing children in the 1970s and 1980s. Juan Carlos Cruz, one of Karadima's victims, said on Twitter that Ezzati has "little time left as archbishop of Santiago, but his new mission of answering for his cover-up, lies and other crimes ... has just begun."

LONDON - Details emerged Tuesday of the three London Bridge attackers: a Pakistan-born failed customer service clerk with links to one of Europe's most prolific hate preachers, a Moroccan pastry chef whose partner said he once went swimming rather than see his daughter and an Italian national who told authorities he "wanted to be a terrorist."At least two of the men were known to British intelligence and law enforcement officials, raising questions about whether anything could have been done to stop the attack, which began Saturday when the men drove a rented van into a crowd and then leaped out to stab people who crossed their paths. Seven were killed and nearly 50 wounded. All three of the attackers were shot dead by police.British Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson said it was fair to ask how the attackers "slipped through our net."Security has become a key issue in the run-up to Thursday's general election. British security officials said none of the men was considered violent, but they acknowledged the difficulty of predicting whether extremists will turn dangerous. The assault was the third attack in three months in which most of the assailants had been on authorities' radar at some point.As the investigation expanded to look at how the men knew one another and whether they were part of a larger conspiracy, Pakistani intelligence authorities swooped Tuesday into the town of Jhelum, where Khurum Butt lived until the time he was 7, when he moved to Britain. His cousin, 18-year-old Bilal Dar, told The Associated Press that Butt's uncle was taken in for questioning. It was unclear if he was detained."Our family is hurt by what he did," Dar said in the town about two hours east of Pakistan's capital.

Concerns have been raised as Dadaab refugee camps in Kenya approach overcrowding, with over 225,000 refugees now housed in the four camps. Refugees mainly originate from Somalia, but also come from countries such as Ethiopia, Uganda, and Sudan.In 2011, the UNHCR, the United Nations Refugee Agency, stated that the camps were already at full capacity. However, due to continuous population growth, the camps have been pushed past their limit. In addition, the refugee camps in the area have become overpopulated by a growing number of young people.A team of Kenyan security officers reported that they are increasingly concerned about the overcrowding, citing that it is becoming more difficult to secure the camps. The team mentioned that criminals are taking advantage of the situation, which has been further exacerbated by lack of resources and inadequate funding.The Kenyan government has promised to help alleviate the situation, but no concrete steps have been taken to do so.

The 2019 World Athletics Championships came to a close on Sunday in Helsinki, Finland, with a spectacular celebration of the best track and field athletes from all over the world. With multiple medalists from all around the globe, the Championships provided a thrilling conclusion to an exciting two weeks of competition.The event's star performer was undoubtedly Bahamian sprinter Shaunae Miller-Uibo, who took home gold medals in both the 200 meters and 400 meters events. Her victories highlighted a successful week for the host nation, as Finland's athletes also performed impressively. Sprinter Eetu Viitala took home the gold medal in the men's 400 meters, while the women's 4x400 meter relay team won a surprising bronze medal.The crowds at the games were electric, as tens of thousands of spectators filled the stadium and were eager to watch some of the biggest names in the sport. There was an atmosphere of celebration and pride, as all the athletes and coaches received the appreciation of the enthusiastic spectators.The next edition of the World Athletics Championships will be held in Eugene, Oregon, USA in 2021. Until then, the Helsinki Championships have set a high standard for the next edition of the event and left athletes and fans excited for what lies ahead.

Turkey has blocked access to the Russian news website, Sputnik, a move that has caused international outcry. The website, which was established in 2014 by the Russian government, covers topics ranging from international affairs to culture.The ban, which was instituted by the Turkish government on Wednesday, is in retaliation for the Russian airstrike on Turkish-backed Syrian rebels near the border between Syria and Turkey. In an attempt to contain any unrest, the government issued a statement condemning the attacks as “unacceptable” and said it was acting to protect its citizens.The move has been criticized by many, including Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, who said the action undermined freedom of expression and was an attack on media outlets. He accused Turkey of trying to hide from its citizens “objective information about events happening in Syria”.The European Commission has also weighed in, calling on Turkey to uphold the “freedom of expression and media freedom”. It is urging Turkish authorities to “immediately restore access to Sputnik”.Although the Turkish government said it is determined to protect its citizens, the action has been seen as a further erosion of press freedom in the country. Critics have argued that it shows a disregard for international law and serves as another example of the Turkish government’s attempt to muzzle critical voices.

The Trump administration has officially started the renegotiation process of the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). This move marks the beginning of what is expected to be a lengthy and complex process.The US Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer released a statement on the matter, saying that NAFTA has failed to keep pace with the evolution of the North American economy. He mentioned that the agreement is over two decades old and does not reflect modern standards.Mexico's Secretary of the Economy, Ildefonso Guajardo, responded in a statement of his own, saying that the opening of the NAFTA renegotiation process is an opportunity for Mexico and the US to deepen their commercial relationship in ways that benefit citizens from both countries.The purpose of the NAFTA renegotiation is to modernize the agreement to better fit the needs of North America in the 21st century. The negotiations are expected to focus on various topics such as increasing the market access for agricultural goods, implementing stronger labor and environmental standards, and streamlining regulations.Both Canada and Mexico will be involved in the process, and the negotiation teams will have multiple rounds of talks. The US and Mexico are aiming to complete the renegotiation by the end of 2017, while the US and Canada have not yet set a timeline for their negotiations. It is expected that the negotiation process will have a wide-reaching impact on all three countries. With the process officially underway, analysts will be closely watching to see how it unfolds.

Myanmar has established a commission of inquiry to probe allegations of human rights abuses in conflict-torn Rakhine state, authorities said Monday, as the country faces growing calls for accountability over accusations of ethnic cleansing against Rohingya Muslims.The four-person commission will be comprised of two local and two international members — Filipino diplomat Rosario Manalo and Kenzo Oshima, Japan's former ambassador to the U.N. — the Myanmar President's Office said in a statement. Manalo, 82, a former undersecretary of foreign affairs, will chair the commission.The two local members are lawyer Mya Thein and Aung Tun Thet, an economist and former UN official. Aung Tun Thet was last year appointed by de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi to a key role in Myanmar's response to the Rakhine crisis, and in April told a Bangladesh newspaper that Myanmar had "no intention of ethnic cleansing.""

MADRID - Spain heads to the polls Sunday for its most divisive and open-ended election in decades, set to result in a fragmented parliament in which the far-right will get a sizeable presence for the first time since the country’s return to democracy.After a tense campaign dominated by emotive issues, notably national identity and gender equality, the likelihood that any coalition deal will take weeks or months to be brokered will feed into a broader mood of political uncertainty across Europe.At least five parties from across the political spectrum have a chance of being in government and they could struggle to agree on a deal between them, meaning a repeat election is one of several possible outcomes.A few things are clear, however, based on opinion polls and conversations with party insiders. No single party will get a majority; the Socialist party of outgoing Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez is leading the race; and there will be lawmakers from the far-right Vox party.Beyond that, the result is too close to call.Spanish Prime Minister and Socialist Party candidate Pedro Sanchez, center, smiles for a photo during an election campaign event in Toledo, central Spain, April 26, 2019. What undecided voters do in this tight race will shape the fortunes of the two political blocs that loosely took shape during campaigning that ended Friday.?

The United States government has announced the end of its boycott of Indian opposition leader Mamata Banerjee. The leader of the All India Trinamool Congress party has been subject to US sanctions since 2020 over accusations of human rights abuses.The Treasury Department stated that the US was responding to significant steps that Banerjee has taken in recent months to support the Indian government's efforts to promote political freedoms and human rights, and to bolster the nation's economy.Banerjee has been an outspoken critic of Prime Minister Narendra Modi and has recently taken steps to distance her party from the Bharatiya Janata Party, which currently governs India.In a statement, the US said, "Mamata Banerjee has demonstrated a strong commitment to improving the human rights and political freedoms of her constituents, and her leadership has served as a counterweight to the government's oppressive policies."The decision to lift the sanctions is the latest move by the Biden administration to improve relations between the US and India, and to show support for India's burgeoning democracy. It comes just days after President Biden's historic visit to India, during which he lauded India's commitment to democracy and reiterated the need for both countries to work together.

Afghan presidential candidates have demanded that incumbent president Ashraf Ghani step down or withdraw from the upcoming presidential election, citing a lack of confidence in his candidacy.In a statement issued on Tuesday, Abdullah Abdullah, leader of the opposition-backed Stability and Partnership team, urged Ghani to "retire peacefully," adding that allowing him to stay in the race would lead to a "damaged" and "confused" electoral process."The Afghan people will be the biggest losers if the election is disrupted due to [Ghani's] unilateral and stubborn decision to hold onto power at all costs," said Abdullah.Ahmad Wali Massoud, the deputy leader of the Stability and Partnership team, also spoke out against Ghani's decision to stay in the race, saying it "threatens the unity and national solidarity of Afghanistan."Ghani, who is seeking a second five-year term, has dismissed the accusations that he has become a "dictator" and says his candidacy is in line with Afghan laws. His spokesperson, Sediq Sediqqi, has accused the opposition of attempting to derail the election process.Despite the pressure, Ghani appears determined to stay in the race, as his campaign team has vowed to challenge any attempt to disqualify him.The political tensions come ahead of the long-delayed election, slated for September 28, in which more than 12 million Afghans are registered to vote.

The Netherlands has suspended foreign aid to Kenya citing concerns of corruption in the East African nation.The Dutch government announced the suspension on Wednesday, and said that the move was in response to a wide range of corruption allegations made against the Kenyan government in recent months.The Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement that “all development cooperation and funds from the Netherlands to the Kenyan government will be suspended until further notice.”The decision is set to affect around €75 million ($90 million) of aid over the next three years.The Kenyan government has denied any allegations of corruption, calling them “baseless”.However, Dutch Foreign Minister Stef Blok said that “there is too little progress with the necessary reforms in the fight against corruption and the proper functioning of public administration.”It is not the first time that the Netherlands has taken action against alleged corruption in Kenya.

Once again, thunderstorms have forced a delay for the launch of the U.S. space shuttle Endeavour.It is the second evening in a row that NASA has canceled the liftoff due to weather. The latest postponement Monday comes after two abortive attempts last month because of hydrogen fuel leaks.The space agency has until Tuesday or Wednesday to get Endeavour into orbit and up to the International Space Station. Otherwise, flight managers have to wait until near the end of July to make way for a Russian supply ship to launch and dock at the station.The seven-member shuttle crew plans to conduct a two-week mission to deliver the final piece of a Japanese laboratory known as Kibo. Kibo means "hope" in Japanese.Kibo amounts to a porch to be installed on the space station. It is designed to expose experiments to the vacuum of space.Endeavour will carry astronaut Timothy Kopra to take the place of Japan's Koichi Wakata, who has been on the space station since March.

Former Donald Trump campaign chair Paul Manafort has gone to trial on charges of financial fraud and tax evasion in a federal court in Virginia. Manafort stands accused of defrauding banks and the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) out of millions of dollars through a scheme that involved undisclosed offshore accounts and unreported loans.The federal trial marks the first criminal trial stemming from Special Counsel Robert Mueller's ongoing investigation into alleged Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election.The charges brought against Manafort include bank fraud, tax fraud, failing to file reports of foreign bank and financial accounts, and several others. He has pleaded not guilty.Manafort has already been in jail for several months. In June, he was placed in jail after being accused of witness tampering.Testimony is expected to start on Tuesday, with prosecutor Uzo Asonye opening the government's case. The trial is expected to last two to three weeks.The outcome of this trial could have far-reaching implications for the Mueller investigation as well as the upcoming midterm elections.

FIFA, the governing body of world football, has opened a formal investigation into Germany’s bid for the 2006 World Cup.The inquiry, which is being conducted by the Adjudicatory Chamber of FIFA’s Ethics Committee, is looking into allegations that the German Football Association (DFB) paid bribes to secure the hosting rights for the 2006 tournament. The DFB has denied any wrongdoing.The allegations were first reported by the German newspaper Der Spiegel in October 2015. According to the report, the DFB had made a payment of 6.7 million Euros to Robert Louis-Dreyfus, the late former president of the Adidas Group, to secure a vote for the German bid.The decision to open the inquiry follows a preliminary investigation by FIFA’s Ethics Committee, which concluded that the allegations warranted a formal investigation.FIFA President Gianni Infantino said that “the integrity of the FIFA World Cup bidding process must be upheld” and expressed his confidence in the Ethics Committee to conduct a “thorough and comprehensive” investigation.The 2006 World Cup was hosted by Germany and was won by Italy. The tournament was widely praised for its organization and atmosphere.

Disgraced Italian football club Juventus is appealing its punishment for match fixing to a civil court, and risks further sanctions from the Italian federation and the world governing body, FIFA.The Turin-based club was stripped of its last two Serie A titles, relegated to the second division, and docked 17 points for its part in a match fixing scandal.Juventus said the penalty was too severe and started the appeal process before the Lazio regional court near Rome. A Juventus spokesman said Thursday's action merely notified the court of the club's intention to appeal but is not the official documentation. A hearing is scheduled for September 6.The Italian Football Federation has threatened further sanctions for taking the matter to civil court, including deducting another three points.The Italian governing body acted after FIFA threatened to bar all Italian teams - including clubs and the World Cup-winning national team - from international competition.

The United Nations’ High Commissioner for Human Rights, Michelle Bachelet, is set to visit Venezuela this week.The UN representative's visit aims to assess the human rights situation in the country. This visit was announced in a joint press statement by the UN Human Rights Office and the Venezuelan government.The statement confirmed that Bachelet will be traveling to Caracas on Wednesday, and meeting with the President, Nicolás Maduro, as well as other government officials. Bachelet will also visit different locations throughout the country to assess the human rights situation and assess the effectiveness of the country's institutions in protecting human rights.During her visit, Bachelet will meet with victims of human rights violations, as well as representatives of civil society organizations. She will also analyze the work of the Attorney General's Office and the Public Defender's Office in Venezuela. The UN mission will also be looking into issues such as forced displacement, arbitrary arrests, and lack of due process.

KAFR KANDIL, Egypt - Official results from Egypt's historic presidential election are not expected until next week, but early speculation after the first two-day round is showing a race too close to call. The rural vote appears as divided as it is elsewhere.As Egyptians await the results of their first truly open presidential election, fault lines between Islamists and old guard secularists appear to cut across the nation. In the village of Kafr Kandil, south of Cairo, the choice plays well with the largely conservative rural vote: some seek stability in religion, others in past performance. Many of the latter look to veteran diplomat Amr Moussa, who along with former Air Force chief Ahmed Shafik, promises a return to pre-uprising law and order, minus the corruption. Outside the village school, which is serving as the village polling station, Shadia Ewis, a housewife and mother of five, hopes Moussa wins. She thinks he's a "respectable man" who "could control the country." Her friend and fellow housewife, Magda Hassan, agrees. She says she wants Moussa to institute reforms, so that it won't be like it was under the old government, when everything was exploited. Getting a fair shake from the government is a key concern of Islamist candidates' supporters, too. Farmer Ali Hassan Abdel Baki believes the best man for the job is the Muslim Brotherhood's Mohamed Morsi. Sitting in the bright sunshine, his fields of tomatoes and grains behind him, Abdel Baki says "there is unfinished business." He says a lot of people are out of work, and the next leader, "with God's help, will look after the poor."

JOHANNESBURG - As South Africa joins the rest of the world in commemorating World AIDS Day, experts say the country's women below age 25 have a high HIV infection rate and studies show they are getting the virus from older men.Lolobrigitha Tsupa, 30, was 23 when she learned she was HIV positive. She was looking for a man who could satisfy her craving for a fast and high-flying life. But Tsupa said she got more than that. "I met this man who had money, drove nice cars, and the man was very old, old enough to be my father. He would buy me things, gifts, and he would take me out," she said. "That is the life I wanted to live and I did not have that at home. Anyway, that is where I got the virus from."Tsupa’s story is similar to that of 28-year-old Brenda Masango. Masango said she discovered she was HIV positive in 2007, while still a student at the University of Tswane. She said it all started when her parents cut their financial support to punish her bad behavior. "I had to buy clothes for myself" and cover food costs at school, she said.

Senegal has seen widespread protests this week as citizens are angered by the ongoing scandal involving the International Monetary Fund (IMF). The scandal has rocked the country, with accusations of mismanagement and misuse of public funds amounting to millions of dollars. The protests have been led by a group of activists called the March for Decency, who have been highly vocal in their condemnation of those responsible. The movement is gathering momentum, with thousands of citizens taking to the streets in major cities across the country.So far, the movement has achieved success in forcing the government to launch an investigation into the scandal, which is to be headed by the country’s Prime Minister, Abdoul Mbaye. In a press conference held on Monday, he declared that any “wrongdoing must be met with swift and decisive punishment”.But the activists remain unsatisfied, and are calling for more significant action to be taken to ensure that those responsible face the consequences of their actions. The protests show no signs of letting up, as citizens continue to make their voices heard in the capital city of Dakar.The scandal has revealed the deep-rooted issues of corruption and lack of accountability in the country, and protesters hope that their action will spark a shift in the way the government governs its citizens. The future of the protests is yet to be determined, but it is clear that the scandal is far from over.

Eleven people, including several journalists, have been killed in a brutal attack on a convoy of vehicles near the town of Raga in Western Bahr el Ghazal state in South Sudan, officials said Monday.Western Bahr el Ghazal Governor Rizik Zachariah Hassan called for flags to be flown at half-staff around the state for three days. He expressed his condolences to the families of the dead and vowed the state government will not stop working because of the attack.Newly appointed Raga County Commissioner Maradom James was among the four people wounded in the attack on Sunday.We were not expecting to survive... So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs.James' private secretary, Justin Abo Saleh, who was in the same car as the county commissioner, said the assault came out of the blue and was ferocious. He said the two vehicles came under a hail of bullets from both sides of the road.“We were not expecting to survive," he said. "We talked to our driver that he should not stop and already these people started firing on us. So many guns, even Kalashnikovs and PKMs."The car that Saleh and James were in was able to get away. After awhile, they returned to where the brutal assault had taken place and found a gruesome scene.The victims had been shot and then hacked to pieces before their bodies were set alight, Saleh said.

Dr. Greg Mills, National Director of the South African Institute of International Affairs, says the Middle East crisis has a great deal of relevance to South Africa and the rest of the continent. He says South Africa has Muslim and Jewish populations, while many other African countries have large Muslim populations, such as Nigeria and Sudan.He says Africa has an interest in the Middle East partly due to its own colonial past and developmental challenges. The crisis does, however, divert attention away from Africa.He says some African leaders could contribute to the Middle East peace process, such as Nelson Mandela. But he says those leaders are currently busy trying to bring peace in such places as Burundi, Angola and the DRC.He says the historical experience of Africa, especially South Africa, has lessons to offer to Israel and the Palestinians. Dr. Mills says there?

Tensions in Thailand are rapidly escalating as political protests grow in intensity. The current government, led by Prime Minister Prayut Chan-o-cha, has been in power since 2014 following a military coup, and has been met with strong opposition by activists calling for reform and a return to democracy.In recent weeks, thousands of protesters have been gathering in Bangkok and other cities to demand the removal of the Prime Minister, as well as constitutional reforms and an end to harassment of activists. Protests have been met with a strong response from the government, who have arrested dozens of protesters for "causing disturbances", and have shut down social media platforms such as Facebook and Twitter in an effort to limit the spread of the movement.The political situation in Thailand has become increasingly precarious in the past few days, with protesters vowing to continue their demonstrations until their demands are met. This is a major challenge to the government, who are facing growing pressure both from within and from abroad. As the conflict continues, there are fears that the situation could deteriorate further unless a resolution is reached soon.

Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro is planning to tackle the country's pension reform in a piecemeal fashion, rather than attempting to overhaul it as a single unified effort. This has come as a surprise to many observers, who were expecting the President to push for a full-scale solution to the pension crisis.The pension crisis has been an ongoing issue for Brazil, with the country's current pension system failing to generate the necessary revenues. In 2018, Brazil had a pension deficit of 626.3 billion reais, which has led many to criticize the current system.Bolsonaro has stated that he wants to tackle the problem on a "module by module" basis, focusing on specific parts of the pension system to generate revenue. He stated that the government must show "responsibility and commitment" when it comes to reforms, which will include raising the minimum retirement age and increasing the contribution rate.In addition to tackling the pension crisis, Bolsonaro is also hoping to tackle the country's high unemployment rate. He has promised to create jobs through economic stimulus packages and has proposed several new tax measures to stimulate the economy.While Bolsonaro's decision to tackle the pension crisis on a module-by-module basis is a break from tradition, it may ultimately be more successful than attempting to tackle the entire system all at once. Only time will tell if his approach will pay off, but the country is certainly hoping that it will.

On Tuesday, the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Eritrea began its withdrawal. The withdrawal of the UN Mission in Eritrea and Ethiopia (UNMEE) is part of the country’s new peace agreement, which ended two decades of conflict between the countries. The UN mission will move to Ethiopia to begin its withdrawal, which will take approximately eight weeks to complete. “We have seen the forces of the two countries exercise restraint and commitment to the full implementation of the peace agreement and to the full withdrawal of UNMEE," said the United Nations Secretary General Antonio Guterres in a statement. The UNMEE mission has been in Eritrea since 2000, and had more than 2,500 troops deployed to the region at its peak. However, due to the conflict between the two countries, most of the mission's personnel had to be relocated. The departure of UNMEE comes as a result of the peace agreement signed between the two countries last July. The agreement included steps to demarcate the border between the two countries, which was one of the main causes of the conflict. The withdrawal is a positive sign that the peace agreement is being implemented and that stability is returning to the region. This marks an important milestone in the region's path to peace.

Iran has filed a lawsuit against the United States alleging that Washington's decision in May to impose sanctions after pulling out of a nuclear deal violates a 1955 treaty between the two countries, the International Court of Justice said Tuesday.A State Department official said the application was without merit and the United States would fight it in the court."While we cannot comment on the specifics, Iran's application is baseless and we intend to vigorously defend the United States before the ICJ," a State Department official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, told Reuters.President Donald Trump withdrew the United States from the 2015 nuclear pact with Iran reached by his predecessor Barack Obama and other world powers, and ordered tough U.S. sanctions on Tehran. Under the 2015 deal, which Trump sees as flawed, Iran reined in its disputed nuclear program under U.N. monitoring and won a removal of international sanctions in return.The ICJ, which is based in The Hague and is also known as the World Court, is the United Nations tribunal for resolving international disputes. Iran's filing asks the ICJ to order the United States to provisionally lift its sanctions ahead of more detailed arguments."

GENEVA - A new report by the Inter-Parliamentary Union finds that worldwide, members of parliament in Africa and Asia are at greater risk of intimidation, imprisonment, and other abuse than in other regions.The report says members of parliament are subject to multiple abuses, including death, torture, threats, arbitrary arrest and detention. The Inter-Parliamentary Union says its Committee on the Human Rights of Parliamentarians is investigating the cases of 311 MPs from 41 countries - a 13 percent increase over 2013.The data reveal 38 percent of the MPs who faced governmental abuse are from Africa, 25 percent from Asia, 18 percent from the Middle East and North Africa, 14 percent from the Americas and five percent from Europe.IPU human rights program manager Rogier Huizenga said the three worst cases in Africa were Democratic Republic of Congo, Zambia and Eritrea. They represent 21.5 percent of abuse cases on the continent.“DRC - there are a number of serious cases where due process is a concern, where freedom of expression is a concern. Eritrea is the famous case of the G-11, the members of parliament who wrote a critical letter to the authorities, to the president, Afwerki, 2001, and were taken away in September that year and were never seen again. And, then the case in Zambia where there are concerns about the use of the Public Order Act and the limitations that that brings along for the right to freedom of assembly,” said Huizenga.In Asia, the IPU cites 78 MPs from 12 countries who are under threat.It singles out the Maldives as the worst violator.

New research shows that the number of premature births is rising, with worrying implications for the health of newborns.The World Health Organization estimates that 15 million babies around the world are born too early every year. That figure is steadily rising, with a prevalence of 10 percent in some countries. The global preterm birth rate has increased by 11 percent since 2000, according to the WHO.The consequences of premature birth can be dire. Babies born too early are at higher risk of death and disability compared to those born at full term. They may also experience delays in physical growth and development, as well as breathing, hearing, and vision problems.The underlying causes of preterm birth are poorly understood. However, factors that increase the risk include poverty, tobacco smoking, unhealthy diet, lack of access to health services, and certain infections.Various initiatives have been launched in recent years in an effort to reduce the rate of preterm births. In the United States, for example, the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development has established a network to better understand the factors that contribute to preterm birth and how to prevent it.This data highlights the need for further research and global awareness into the risks of premature births. Until these preventative measures are put into place, these alarming statistics suggest that the problem of premature births will continue to affect newborns worldwide.

The tension between the US and China is palpable as Manila leader, Rodrigo Duterte, is set to reveal his stance on the South China Sea. Duterte, who recently reached his first anniversary as president, has so far indicated a willingness to pursue an amicable solution to the dispute with the Chinese in the region.Washington has expressed concern in the past that the Filipino leader might move to soften the Philippines' stance against Beijing's claims, which have been heavily criticized by the international community. After taking office, Duterte has taken a number of steps to improve relations with China, including a state visit in October 2016.The South China Sea is a contentious issue in the region due to the overlapping territorial claims of China, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Brunei. The situation has escalated in recent years, with the US reinforcing its stance against Beijing by sending warships to patrol the disputed waters.Duterte has taken a more conciliatory stance compared to his predecessor, Benigno Aquino. Aquino initiated an international arbitration case against China, which the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague ruled in favor of the Philippines in July 2016.The Filipino leader's speech, which is expected to take place this month, could set the tone for the next several years of diplomatic relations between the US and China. Both Washington and Beijing are expecting to hear Duterte's views on the South China Sea situation and hoping that it will result in a constructive outcome.

Chinese military vessels are now operating in the Northern Atlantic, and Russian submarines are prowling those same waters at a pace not seen since the end of the Cold War, the Navy’s top admiral told VOA in an exclusive interview.Chief of Naval Operations Adm. John Richardson said China's military movements from the North Atlantic into the Mediterranean Sea create a "new dynamic.""Even five years ago, we wouldn't have seen anything like this,” Richardson said.According to Richardson, the Chinese navy is a global one that is both "ready and capable" of operating wherever Beijing wants.“They're certainly a pacing competition for us in terms of the naval threat,” he told VOA.However, Chinese operations near the United States' eastern shore are not as threatening as Russian vessels lurking below the ocean’s surface. NATO allies from North America to Europe are increasingly concerned about the uptick of Russian submarine activity in the North Atlantic.“We're talking about more (activity) than we've seen in 25 years,” Richardson said.U.S. officials worry that Moscow may try to use its submarines to cut or tap into undersea cables that connect the two continents.Secretary of Defense Jim Mattis, speaks to reporters at the Pentagon, July 27, 2018.

TAIPEI - Police clashed with hundreds of protesters in Taipei Monday after the group upset over a trade deal with China broke into the government’s chief office complex. As hundreds more remain camped out in Taiwan’s parliament, the government weighs what to do next. About 2,000 police officers expelled hundreds of protesters from Taiwan’s guarded cabinet offices before dawn on Monday. The government mobilized riot squads and water cannons to oust demonstrators in a five-hour struggle. Protesters want to stop quick approval of the trade deal, calling that approach risky as China claims sovereignty over self-ruled Taiwan and wants political reunification. Lin Nan-hsin, a 20-year-old protester from a university in central Taiwan, was among those expelled by police. He said there are two camps of protesters, one that advocates peace and the other that prefers a more extreme form of protest as the only way of getting the government’s attention. Lin said that in the end, there was a discussion with the lead protest planners about whether to break into the cabinet complex and finally a go-ahead was given. Taiwan and China signed a service trade pact in June following several other trade and investment agreements reached since 2008.

Five people have died in a tragic helicopter crash in Leicester, England, including Leicester City Football Club's Thai owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha.The helicopter, which had been traveling from the King Power Stadium in Leicester, plummeted to the ground shortly after 8pm on Saturday night, according to reports. The cause of the crash is still unknown.The four other individuals who died in the crash were believed to have been members of Vichai’s entourage. No other casualties have been reported.Leicestershire Police released a statement, saying they were working with the Air Accident Investigation Branch to investigate the incident.The helicopter crash has sent shockwaves throughout the sporting world, with Leicester City Football Club releasing a statement of its own in tribute to its former owner.“It is with the deepest regret and a collective broken heart that we confirm our chairman, Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha, was among those to have tragically lost their lives on Saturday evening when a helicopter carrying him and four other people crashed outside King Power Stadium,” the statement read.Football teams across the country have taken to social media to offer their condolences, and Leicester City players and staff were seen in tears outside the King Power Stadium on Sunday morning. The thoughts and prayers of the entire football community are with Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha's family and friends.

With legislation overhauling taxes and health care on an uncertain path, President Donald Trump returned to the familiar. Trump brought 52 business leaders from New York City to the White House Tuesday to talk about another favorite campaign issue — infrastructure and economic growth. The U.S. economy has so far proven to be a point of pride for a presidency that has otherwise gotten off to a rocky start. Trump inherited a stable economy from former President Barack Obama, an economic recovery that's heading toward its eighth year. But Trump believes he can do more for business. Trump and several of his top aides emphasized plans to cut red tape and jumpstart infrastructure projects at Tuesday's meeting, while also previewing for the CEOs other priorities that include shortening flight times for airplanes, increasing the power grid's efficiency and targeting programs to improve job training. At one point the president had an aide come on stage to hold up a long scroll of the government's approval process for building a highway. The president then pledged to eliminate more than 90 percent of the regulations involved and "still have safety.'' He provided no details. The administration has committed to directing as much as $1 trillion for infrastructure over the next decade, although it has yet to release policy specifics. Transportation Secretary Elaine Chao recently said she expects a plan will be unveiled later this year. But getting a measure through Congress could be difficult given the Republican majority in both chambers and their desire to reduce tax rates as much as possible.

ASUNCION - Security forces surrounded Paraguay's Congress on Tuesday while lawmakers argued over a possible change in law that would allow President Horacio Cartes to run for re-election, a move that the opposition says would weaken democratic institutions.A bill allowing presidents to run for a second five-year term was defeated in the legislature last year.This week a group of senators asked for a special session that the opposition interpreted as the start of a new campaign by Cartes and his coalition to enable presidential re-election.Paraguayans taking part in the “Long March” protest, a week-long walk from the interior to the capital, chant slogans against President Horacio Cartes, in Asuncion, Paraguay, Feb. 13, 2017.Opposition leaders and dissident members of Cartes' party accused him of shaking the country's democratic foundations by ordering that Congress be surrounded by police and soldiers.“We have to safeguard the republic,” said Senator Blanca Ovelar, a member of Cartes' Colorado Party who has broken with the president. “This is a situation of institutional breakdown.”Soft drink and tobacco mogul Cartes was elected to a five-year term in 2013. His strongest backers want him to be allowed to run for another term next year. Critics say a constitutional change aimed at benefiting a sitting president would be unfair.The Inter-American Development bank is holding a regional meeting in Asuncion starting on Thursday. Security consultancies International SOS and Control Risks issued a statement warning conference goers to avoid the vicinity of the Congress building in case tensions escalate.On Wednesday, thousands of subsistence farmers are expected to come to capital city Asuncion to lobby for agrarian reform.

Aretha Franklin, the "Queen of Soul", will be laid to rest in Detroit on August 31st, as per her family's wishes. She passed away from pancreatic cancer on August 16th at her home in Detroit at age 76.Aretha Franklin was born in Memphis, Tennessee, but her family moved to Detroit, Michigan, in the 1950s. She began her career as a gospel singer and went on to become one of the most beloved and successful singers in history, with a vast discography of classic hits such as "Respect", "Think", and "Chain of Fools".The funeral for Aretha Franklin will take place at Greater Grace Temple in Detroit, according to the Rev. Robert Smith Jr., senior pastor. The service is expected to be a grand affair with many prominent artists and speakers in attendance, including former President Bill Clinton and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The event will also be streamed live online, allowing fans to pay their respects from around the world. Aretha Franklin's fans have been mourning her passing since the news broke on August 16th, and they now have the chance to say goodbye to the legendary artist in her home of Detroit, where she made her mark on music history.

In Kenya, sending money home to villages and farms from the city used to be problematic. Many people in rural areas do not have access to banking, making it difficult for them to receive and send money. But a revolutionary mobile telephone system is making it easy to move money, changing Kenyan society. The system was the first of its kind in the world.As Stephen Mbugua works on his farm a half-hour drive from the capital Nairobi, his mobile phone beeps. He is getting a text message saying that his son has sent the elderly farmer some money - through the mobile telephone.Mbugua is a customer of a service called MPESA, offered by a mobile phone company called Safaricom.People who wish to transfer money through their mobile phones can do so at locations across Kenya.And that is good news for Mbugua, who says the service saves him time and money. "I used to go to Nairobi or to any bank to pay my bills. But right now, since MPESA came, I do not go to Nairobi, I just pay my bill from here," he said.Phelister Omari, 22, who works in a hospital in Nairobi, is sending money to her mother. She fills out a form with the amount she wishes to send, plugs that amount into her telephone, and gives the clerk the amount plus extra for charges.People who are sent money go to the agent with their mobile phone, sign a form, and receive the cash.Omari says she appreciates the service. "It is very fast. The MPESA, they are available everywhere.

At least five people were killed and several others injured in an attack on a mosque in Damascus on Tuesday.Witnesses said that a group of unidentified gunmen attacked the al-Rifai mosque in the Barzeh neighbourhood of Damascus. The attackers reportedly opened fire on worshippers inside the mosque.The victims, mostly women and children, were said to have been praying at the time.Syrian security forces arrived at the scene soon after the attack and started to evacuate casualties and take the injured to local hospitals. The identity of the attackers remains unclear, and no group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack.The Syrian government has condemned the attack, calling it a “heinous act of terror”, and vowed to bring those responsible to justice.The attack on the mosque follows a spate of violence in Damascus over the past few weeks. On Monday, a bombing near a school killed six people, while there have also been reports of clashes between government forces and opposition fighters in the city.

A Papua New Guinea court has ruled Australia's detention of asylum seekers on its northern island of Manus is illegal.The court said Tuesday the detentions of the asylum seekers violates their constitutional right to personal liberty. It ordered the governments of Australia and Papua New Guinea to take immediate steps to end the detention of more than 800 people at the facility.Under Australia's immigration law, anyone intercepted trying to reach its shores by boat is sent for processing to camps in Papua New Guinea and the island nation of Nauru.Australian Immigration Minister Peter Dutton said the ruling would not change Australia's policy of offshore detention. "No one who attempts to travel to Australia illegally by boat will settle in Australia," Dutton said."Those in the Manus Island Regional Processing Center found to be refugees are able to resettle in Papua New Guinea. Those found not to be refugees should return to their country of origin."Detention Camp Sites on Manus Island, Papua New GuineaHuman rights groups have long criticized Australia's asylum seeker policy, which the government says is aimed at protecting its borders and preventing dangerous ocean crossings in unsafe boats."
